text: Poured from bottle thanks ClarkVV 2012 vintage Whallezz son cola color with a nice tan head and great lacing. Aromas of brown sugar dark fruit bourbon toffee. Taste is amazing not boozy balanced sweetness raisin fig toffee caramel. Wow.

Amazing beer. Great balance. Aged from 2013 and drank in April of 2017. Great beer!

Jag har så många öl att betygsätta avyer en stor åldrig öldrinkning med min goda vän Jesse, att jag inte har tid att betygsätta alla dessa och i många fall hade för öl att minnas storheten i dessa öl. Till ära för mitt svenska arv, jag skickar detta på svenska för alla recensioner från den dagen. Tack Gud för god öl !!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, many thanks Max! Dark brown color with tan head. Aroma is bourbon, booze, liquorice, raisin. Taste is chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and booze again, liquorice, raisins, a bit of a spicy tanginess (cinnamon maybe indeed). Silky and viscous mouthfeel. Despite the booziness it retains a nice balance. A beauty!

Bottle. Pours ruby black with a decent head. Aroma is strong bourbon, vanilla, booze. Body is super heavy and strong, boozy and sweet. Vanilla, liquorice, wood, bourbon, cinnamon. Soft carbonation, sticky texture, viscous. Long sweet nut palate. Balanced, but really strong, a classical sipper.

0.75l bottle shared with The Tasting Crew. Been looking forward to this one. It pours a deep dark brown, near black body in the glass and it has a medium sized slowly sidesticking an islandy beige head. Lovely nose. Woody and vanilla infused for sure. I get chocolate, some dark sweetness soaked rum raisins. Malt spicy drops. Cinnamon spicy almost and traces of whisky. Smells really good. It tastes quite good, I have to say. More woody and vanilla infused in the taste actually. Feels thick and oily on the mouthfeel and the about average on the carbonation. A little chocolate with dark caramel and dry licorice. Lots of flavor. A really good one. 18.02.2016

(On tap @ Anvil and Stave, Apr 5/17) Pours a clear dark red brown, with a fine but decent white head and spotty lace. Aroma of crisp, mineral, toffee, raisin, vanilla, wood. Flavour is surprisingly light caramel, some dried pale fruit, oak, vanilla, some boozy bourbon. Body is kind of light and mineral. Boozy. Soft carb. Huh. I expected substantially more richness from the body than was present here. While that crisp feel is interesting, it also seemed to struggle to backstop the barrel character.

Pours opaque chocolate with a decent buff head. Aroma delivers bourbon, roast malt and caramel tones. Flavor nicely echoes the aroma, fairly sweet but not cloying. Mouthfeel features good body and jazzy fizz. More than wee!

750 ml bottle. 2015 vintage. Aromas of bourbon, raisins, a little cola, and sweet roasted malts. Flavors of dark caramel, bourbon, oak, raisins and lots of malts. Much lighter than the barrelled stout and therefore seems more boozy, but still very nice. Doesnt need anymore aging IMHO.

750ml bottle @ Alexs(Serguys Birthday). Pours a mostly opaque brown colour with a small beige head. Nose is huge, rich, and malty... lots of bourbon and oak. Flavour is a spicey-esque profile that derives from the bourbon heat and oak while the sweetness tames it.
Bottle - Vintage 2015 - Crazy bourbon hot woody notes. Deep dark brown with a small light brown head. Big dark toffee notes and tons of bourbon notes. A bit too big and boozy notes.

750ml bottle (thx, Robert G.!) at Alexs in honor of my birthday and CPA PREP finish. Vintage 2015. Pours a dark brown with beige head. Aroma is sweet, dark fruits, bourbon, woody, and booziness. Taste is chocolate, oily, still hot, dark fruits, slightly buttery, bourbon. Despite it is still boozy, I love it and it is a very nice sipper.

Bottle shared, 2012 vintage. Pours thick dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aromas of heavy bourbon, vanilla, dark fruits, licorice, light oxidization, chocolate, malt. Taste is malty, vanilla, dark fruits, toffee, butterscotch, huge caramel, porty notes, subtle bitter malty notes.
Good grief this was good. Burnt bread pudding with caramel and molasses touch with oak and bourbon. Nice dark caramel color with a full and smooth palate. Near perfect.

Vintage 2012, gracieuseté de Yannick. Merci lami! Clairement le meilleur scotch ale que jai bu de ma vie. Léquilibre est parfait: ni trop sucrée, ni trop sirupeuse, ni trop alcoolisée. Toute en finesse, le bourbon nest pas trop agressif, même au contraire. Ce dernier a je crois aminci cette bière dont la base est plutôt lourde pour moi. Effervescence parfaite et rondeur impeccable. Saveurs de fruits noirs, de caramel, de douce mélasse. Longue en bouche sans jamais écoeurer, un grand coup de coeur pour moi que cette bière qui a déjà 5 ans.
Pours a dark brown off white lacing and some floaties. The aroma is heavy vanilla, caramel, heavy bourbon and toffee

Dark brown color, large head, average to below average lace/retention. Aroma is creamy with notes of bourbon, chocolate, caramel, light vanilla. Full bodied, the barrel changes this beer more than a lot of others. It loses any touch of smoke but gets a sweeter choco-caramel thing going with an extremely drinkable vanilla creamy mouthfeel. Unlike a lot of other bourbon barrel beers, it doesnt have any harshness and the alcohol is completely hidden. A treat, albeit an expensive one.
750ml bottle of 2015 release. Pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Delicious brown sugar and toffee aroma. Intense bourbon at the start. But blows off with some time to breathe. A little hot.
Massive barrel aroma. Unfiltered brown amber caramel color. Foamy oily spiral head. Massive chewy caramel bourbon candy notes. Luscious. Viscous. Boozy, but really well done.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours a deep brown, red-hued body with a small beige head. Nose is creamy caramel, vanilla, biscuits, nuts and hints of wood, red fruits and muscovado sugars. Taste is dark sugars, caramel, cream and hints of alcohol, raisins and nuts. Full body, high to medium carbonation. Very smooth, creamy and elegant smooth ale. Highly integrated and fine-tuned, with the creamy sweet tones complimenting the alcohol and barrel tones.

Strong bourbon aroma. Oak. Like a toned down bourbon. Oak. Not boozy. Im generally not a fan of bourbon beers, but this is so smooth. Vanilla. Thx for the trade Malster85! Shared w Tony watching Blues playoffs.

Bottle [2013] @ weekly tasting shared with Joes and Dutchdrebus to celebrate the fact that the cast which has been on my left leg since March 4th (55 days ago) was removed today.. Thank god for that. I know I have a long way to go as far as full recovery goes, but Im so happy that the cast is gone. Also, thanks to all RB friends who have wished me well during this period. It was and still is really really appreciated. -- [Rating] Nice deep dark red-brown color, small off-white head. Aroma is malts, nice bourbon. Taste malts, again firm bourbon, sweet, dark fruits, raisins, some alcohol, caramel and brown candy sugar. Full body, slow drinker, average to moderate carbonation. Heavy, full and a very very nice beer. Lovely.

Bottle @ benzai. Dark brown colour with no head. Smells sweet, cloyingly sweet, plums, malts, alcohol. Tastes appelstroop, sweet, toffee.. Amazingly deep. Kinda hits ypu like a hammer though. Feel like I need a nap after every two sips. Full body, soft carbo.

Bottle, shared with BBGTC. Pours hazy, dark maroon, with a creamy off white head. Aroma is sweet roasted malts with bread, toffee and heather, as well as cocoa and leather. Full body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is sweet roasted malts with bread, cocoa, leather and wood, as well vanilla and muscovado. Lingering sweet malty finish. Very drinkable, and nicely balanced.

18.02.2016, 0,75l bottle shared @ BBGTC tasting:
Nice creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is very mild and balanced, yet it?s not a wow experience; weeds, dark malts, vanilla, minerals, oak, chocolate, caramel, nuts, bark, dark sugar. Taste is slightly dry boozy, weeds, dark malts, minerals, caramel, chocolate, oak, vanilla, alcohol, nuts, mild bourbon. Medium bitterness, slightly mineraly mouthfeel. Nice and very balanced, but not fantastic...
Bottle shared at rbwg 2016. Oily reddy caramel brown no head. Aroma is barrel, oak, vanilla, boozy, wood. Flavour is composed of spicy cinnamon. Oak, vanilla, cherry. Tangy. Woody. .

Bottle, courtesy of PotjeBier. Thanks! Delicious aroma of strong bourbon vanilla and a little raisin, I could sniff this for hours. Rich taste of earth vanilla, subtle bourbon booze, caramel and some malt body. Fantastic beer.

Bottle thanks to Potjebier, medium sample. Slight hazy copper color, short head. Aroma of lots of toffee and caramel with buckets of cookie and vanilla from bourbon. Quite sweet, toffee, vanilla, bourbon, slight boozy. Wonderful.

75 cl bottle (from an IP trade with richiesd) @ home, shared with caesar, borresteijn & MarcodL. Pours a deep brown color. Off white head, short retention. Aromas: full on bourbon, sweet, vanilla, caramel, really nice. Flavor is sweet, a bit boozy, hints of marzipan. Fairly strong alcohol feel and rather full bodied. Long finish. Wonderful, much nicer than the base beer.

75cl Bottle shared, thanks for tonights beers Potje! Dark brown colour, beige head. Aroma of pure bourbon, sweet, woody, caramel, vanilla, very decadent and lush. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel, full on bourbon, quite sweet but well - balanced, rich and luscious. Full bodied. Great.
From a 75 cl bottle shared at home. Bottled 2/11/14. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of bourbon and oak. Flavors of milk chocolate, bourbon, caramel and butterscotch. Smooth boozy finish. Yum
Bomber to a taster. Hazy brown with thin head. Caramel, vanilla, toasty malts... Smooth bourbon finish... Amazing!!!

Bottle. The pout is a dark brown with a thin head. The aroma is is a nice mix of the bourbon and the toffee. The taste israthler smooth, not too much booze, not overly toffee, a great tasting wee heavy.

Draught at Alesmith Observation Room. Very dark almost black beer with a nice beige head. Fruity caramel aroma, raisins, figs, vanilla, bourbon notes, grapes, chocolate, some cream. Fruity vanilla flavor, grapes, licorice, raisins, woody, figs, some earthy notes. Slightly boozy, but a great beer.

750 mL bottle shared by me with Gus and ebone1988. The pour is a dark muddy brown/light black with a thin collar of khaki head and a couple spots of good lace. The aroma is brilliant. There is a lot of malt and a great light candy. Bourbon barrel. Lots of oak and vanilla with a light booze. The flavor is great. Lots of caramel and a great maltiness. There is a light booze and a great vanilla and oak barrel presence. The mouth feel is thick and creamy with an excellent carbonation and a lingeringly beautiful aftertaste. I love this beer!

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2015 Bottle shared with koleminer20 and Gus. Aroma is wonderful, caramel, toffee, barrel, vanilla, chocolate. Appearance is dark brown and ruby, tan head. Taste is amazing, wonderful vanilla, caramel, toffee, chocolate, marshmallow, and oak, with the perfect balance of booze. The mouthfeel was creamy and delightful, with medium carbonation. Overall, holy shit this is good.

1pt 9.4fl.oz 2012 bottle. Thank you FatPhil! Sugary, raisins, malty, clear bourbon, thin, slimy, not sticky, dry for what it is at the same time, smooth velvety texture. Complex and interesting creation. But is definitely overpriced.

Bottle courtesy of bytemesis, thanks Mike! Pours a rich mahogany, dark amber hues with a toffee colored head that breaks to some fine lacing before settling to a ring. Aromas are very bold roasted malts. Hints of smoke, tobacco, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Taste is loaded with more depth! Dark fruits give way to some nuttiness...roasted pecan...then moves into a caramel/toffee note before the bourbon/oak and vanilla notes move into the finish. Alcohol is very cleanly masked. Full bodied beer....great sipper!!

750 ml bottle, dated 2/20/2014, awesome time to pop! Thanks Adam! Aroma is a blend of a bourbon stout and traces of a Wee Heavy. 

Flavor is off the chain good. The rich English toffee, sugar covered figs, dates, plums. The bourbon has a very mild warming and mellow burn after the sip. Overall the alcohol favor is hidden. Vanilla oak, sweet dark fruits. I got to say the bourbon helps cuts through the sweetness. For me personally, this is not only best in style but but overall an amazing brew no matter the style. Full body with a nice mellow bourbon burn, fucking awesome!

75CL from Ehammond split 3 ways. Bottled February, 2014.

A - Pours black, crimson red with brown edges. a single finger tan head.

S - Aroma is raisin, toffee, and a lot of vanilla. A light sweetness and just a little bit of booze. Smell is weak but really nice. 

T - Holy crap. There is so much vanilla! its delicious. Raisins, toffee for sure with cinnamon, some candy bar like chocolate and nougat and the bourbon is at the finish. Really exceptional taste. 

M - Creamy and thick mouthfeel. boozy, oily, sweet

O - Im thoroughly impressed. This is probably the best scotch ale Ive ever had. Just phenomenal

750ml bottle (300e of overpriced beer tasting) (Alus Celle, Riga) (7+:4:8:4:16=3.9+)
Super raisin aroma, banana, bourbon woodiness too. Taste is similar, palate remarkably light considering how sweet it is, but its not treacly or sticky. Body dominated by nice rich sweet malts. Finish is bourbon and banana. Bloody gorgeous, just a whisker short of a "wow".

750ml bottle (thanks FatPhil). Very dark brown color. Small size, bubbly tan head, stays. Sweet, alcoholic, vineous, raisins, woody, bourbon in aroma. Sweet, raisins, caramel, dark plums, very mellow hops in taste. Nice sweet chocolate in aftertaste. Fantastic brew.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with light brown head. Aroma is sweet, bourbon, malt, caramel. Flavor is sweet, bourbon, caramel, raisins, malt, dark chocolate, oak. Finish is bitter and bourbon. Overall: great brew.

Dark brown beer, small tan head. Nose is very bourbony and oaky, dried fruit, sugar and alcohol. Flavor is a thick mix of roasty and vanilla notes, boozy bourbon, oak, vanilla, dried fruit. Bone dry finish, but still sweet. Strangely, this works.

(Bottle, 0.75 l - 2012 vintage, thanks FatPhil, 20150926) The beer poured deep dark brown and clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had vanilla, sweetness and malts. Palate was full bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were vanilla, malts, sweetness, candi sugar and bitterness. Aftertaste had sweetness, wood and low bitterness. A good barrel aged brew.

Poured from what I believe is a 2013 bottle. 
Aroma is very rich and malty with a medium light bourbon note with medium vanilla and light oak. Fairly strong toffee and caramel notes with hints of chocolate and toasted bread. Some burnt sugar notes as well. Some light alcohol character. 
Pours a dark brown with a medium small, moderately thick, dark tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges where it lingers. Faint lacing and sheets of alcohol. 
Flavor is somewhat sweet with some light toasted bread and hints of roast upfront. Moderately strong toffee and caramel malt notes follow with touches of chocolate and burnt sugar. Some medium light notes of dark fruit such as figs, prunes and plums. Light bourbon and vanilla notes with lighter oak. Medium light bitterness. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low to low carbonation. Low astringency and low, but present alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a really tasty beer with nice, complex malt profile and bourbon barrel notes that really work well with the malt. Alcohol is well hidden and the beer is not too sweet.

Bottle at home - thanks to SlackerMads. Cloudy amber/brown - offwhite head. 
Ryebread. Sweetness. Brown sugar. Bourbon. Light boozy. Raisins. Light bitterness. Nice.... but high sweetness.
Blom fyller 40. Härlig och delikat. Len och lagom inslag av bourbon. Bloms bror gör en insats och letar fram lämpliga rariteter.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Levis place. Thanks Tom L. Very dark brown. Great aroma of bourbon, malt, caramel, nuts, cookies, vanilla, dark fruits, a bit of alcohol. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, nuts, cookies, a chocolate note, vanilla, mild booziness, a sourish hint, and lots of dark fruits in the finish. Medium-bodied, rounded. Great stuff.

Bottle at Mette and Theis. Dark murky brown with a tiny beige head. Bourbon in the nose, vanilla, coconut, toffee. Flavour is also all out bourbon; coconut, vanilla, oak, saw dust, light licorice, brown sugar and dark dried fruits. Full body, light salty, syrupy sweetness, soft carbonation, warming alcohol. Ok for the bourbon barrel fan.

September 12th, 2013 - The Wee Heavy occupies a wee space in my heart. AleSmith sometimes feels like the last tattered bastion for dark brews in San Diego. When I heard they brewed a batch in bourbon barrels, I knew I need to try a sip, or ideally more than just a sip. Its like seeking medicine after weeks and months of IPAs, hoping to slake my thirst for the deep, dark stuff. The bourbon aged version of the Wee Heavy is about on par with the original in appearance. It looks like a cloudy soda, with big, frog-eye bubbles clinging to the sides of the glass near the top. But the aroma makes it clear that this is not the same beer as before. Immediately I recognize (compelled to recognize) that this is punchy brew, strong and heavily laced with bourbon notes. Its tough, redolent, but not too sharp or raw. Theres refinement in there, like the $30 plus bottles one buys to impress a father figure. Also in there are notes of old houses, old furniture, wood, and malt. Theres beer in there, but its staring back at me with a heavy, leather and antique mask. The body is sudsy and medium in weight - not too sharp, not too loud. It takes awhile for the booze to settle in, and once it does, those bourbon notes dominate. But then subtler tastes of Scotch and peat mingle with the bourbon, creating a new and intoxicating harmony. When the dark malty notes pike on, this beer turns into a warm, smoothing and relaxing brew, delivering heady and aged alcoholic notes all the way to a low grumbling and murmuring aftertaste. Its a decidedly different beer than the raw Wee Heavy, but well worth the expense. All thats left is finding a cabin in the forest to pair this with.
A nice beer. Could do with a heavier malt. Very boozie. I do.like it. But not amazing...

One year old bottle... Dark mahogany brown and maroon in color, minimal head... Aroma of caramel, toffee, bourbon, vanilla, light smoke and peated malts... Flavor is rich caramel, vanilla, peat and scotch notes, light whiskey notes on palate... Really nice beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750ml bomber from Rays in Tosa, cellar aged 16 months and shared by all on poker night. Woohoo - a treat! Sweet, great vanilla bourbon nose. Caramel, sweet vanilla, very smooth, some peat. Very sweet caramelly (toffee?) bourbon. Some liked, some didnt. Best for style, likely. 15.7
Bottle - pours Amber. Oak, bourbon, toffee, caramel notes. Nice caramel, bourbon taste. Very smooth and malty. I love this beer!!!
Smell is alcohol and raisins. Taste is heavy malt, chocolate, roast, toffee, and alcohol. Smooth and medium texture with an alcohol bite.

Deep amber color with a nice off-white head. Malty sweet aroma. Sweet, almost lightly tart, malt-bomb like a barley wine.

Notes: Denver Rare Beer Tasting 13

Bottle @ City Beer Store on 1/19/15. Pours a clear dark red, brown color with tan head and lacing. Aroma is strongly bourbon and oak with some vanilla and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is full bodied with light to medium carbonation. Flavor is heavy bourbon and oak, brown sugar and caramel malt with some dark fruits. Overall a nice bourbon, oak-aged beer, but these flavors dominate the base beer (which is excellent).
Tasting with the crew. Big, big, big bourbon. Lots of sweet vanilla, oak, toffee, coke syrup, bourbon, some dark aged fruits, biscuit. Sweet indeed.

Bottle at tasting. Thanks to BenH. Pours hazy dark brown, thin tan head. Aromas of bourbon booze, vanilla, wood, chocolate. Taste is gnarly, chewy wood, bourbon. Preferred the non-barrel version to be honest. Hard work to enjoy.

Bottle @ Appellation Comely Bank tasting, thanks to BenH.
Appearance - dark brown with a decent head.
Nose - burnt wood and booze, then chocolate.
Taste - more chocolate, not getting the nutty malt though. Then booze and wood notes close out the finish.
Palate - medium to full bodied with a big woody middle section that leads into a woody and boozy finish.
Overall - unfortunately, this isnt a patch on the non-oaked version which was superb.
Bottle at Appellation. Pours deep murky brown, nose is huge vanilla, toffee, berries, caramel, taste is chewy toffee, caramel, bourbon, fruity.
Not going to win any awards for drinkability any time soon, but the flavors are very nice. Sweet toffees, hints of dried figs, a nice wash of bourbon that adds some heat and cinnamon. Very solid.

750 with the crew and part of Alesmith day. Man a good wee heavy is one of my favorite things and you dont find them very often. This one has so much of what I love going on. Vanilla and cola flavors with a good sweetness and a bunch of chewy malt. Little bit of oak and wood notes. Good bourbon sweetness to add a little more depth to the beer.
Bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, nuts, oak, tootsie roll. Taste of toffee, oak, cookie, plenty of vanilla. Nicely sweet and clean.

Bottle. Almost clear deep brown liquid with small light tan head. Aroma of vanilla, dark fruit, bourbon, toffee, light wood, caramel, nuts and light raw sugar. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with notes of bourbon, toffee, vanilla, light chocolate and raw sugar. Medium to full bodied with light to medium carbonation and light sticky mouthfeel. Really nice and malty. Great barel notes.

From a bottle (75 cl), courtesy of _angst_. Clear chestnut, medium beige head. Intense malty aroma with bready, nutty and bisquity notes. Well integrated barrel aromas, but I think I prefer the original.

Got in a trade with swingracex. 750 ml bottle into snifter; 2013 vintage, bottled on 2/11/2014. Pours hazy nearly opaque dark brown color with a small foamy khaki head with poor retention, that reduces to a small ring of lace that lingers. Light spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining a thin cap. Aromas of big caramel, toast, toffee, brown sugar, raisin, prune, fig, date, licorice, light chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, light butterscotch/coconut/leather, and toast/oaky earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel notes; with good strength. A fair amount of noticeable alcohol, but subsides as it reaches room temperatures. Taste of big caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, raisin, plum, fig, date, licorice, light chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, light butterscotch/coconut/leather, and toast/oaky earthiness. Light amount of tannic oak bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toffee, toast, brown sugar, raisin, plum, licorice, light chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, oak, light butterscotch/coconut/leather and oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity and robustness of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; with a great malt/barrel balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light carbonation and fairly full bodied; with a very smooth and moderately creamy/slick mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome barrel aged scotch ale style. All around great complexity and balance of dark/bready malt, fruity yeast, and bourbon barrel flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the big ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle courtesy of rlgk. Pours dark wooden brown with a frothy offwhite head that quickly dissipates while leaving some small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel., biscuits, smoked grains, baked pears, vanilla fudge, charred wood, bourbon alcohol and roasted nuts. Taste is sweet and malty with caramel, toffee, sweet dark bread, vanilla fudge, charred wood, baked pears, pears, peat, moist soil, alcohol and moist hay. Mouthfeel is soft, round, viscous, tiny boozy and near full bodied. Finish is sweet, slightly bitter and malty with caramel, toffee, peat, charred wood, peat, moist soil. hay and bourbon alcohol. Tasty but I found it a bit too estery for my taste.

I liked it in short samples. Murky brown flattish pour. Aroma is heavy bourbon and plums which is mostly all i get on the nose. Taste is very sweet and decadent but hard to drink. Slow sipper for sure. Plums soaked in bourbon, light tobacco, and leaves. Finishes sweet and boozey. Good but tough.
woah this was sweet. It was complex and great barrel flavors and all that . but waayyyyyy too sweet. I want to hook up a brewery i support but this was undrinkable after 6 ozs. Sorry bruh.
Pours black with a low tan head. Aromas of caramel, citrus, bourbon, raisins, honey. Taste is caramel, bourbon, raisins, citrus, dates, muscovado sugar. Mouthfeel is smooth with medium carbonation.
Pours murky deep brown with flat light tan head. Aroma of vanilla, butterscotch, toffee. Taste is boozy sweet with vanilla, toffee, dried fruit. Body is rich and sweet with soft carbonation.

Des vents de caramel vanillé envahissent la place immédiatement, tout se passe comme prévu. Le corps onctueux transporte sur ses courbes les sucres martelés par le bourbon chaud. Avec une telle bière de base, difficile de se tromper....Surtout si on sappelle Alesmith.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2014 Big bottle thanks to Johan (non ratebeer). Sampled on October 31, 2014.Hazy dark brown color, tan head. Sweet, raisins, light smoked, caramel taste. Sweet, caramel, raisin aftertaste. Medium to high CO2 fizzy mouthfeel. Also vanilla, bourbon taste and aftertaste. Sweet, some alcohol, raisin, vanilla, bourbon scent. Lovely nice stuff.
Bottle shared at Darkness day. Pours dark brown almost black with no head. Strong wiskey smell. Taste smooth with some scotch notes. Really good beer.
Bomber - 2009 vintage. Super dark brown pour. Oily looking. Wood and vanilla. Super smooth. Lower carbonation. Delicious.

2014 bottle. Aroma is milder with expected and features sweet and boozy bourbon and toffee sweetness. Murky dark mahogany-amber in color. Smooth-as-silk taste of very moderate bourbon (surprising since this beer is not even a year old), decadent caramel and toffee with faint baked brown sugar. A dry burnt barley taste becomes prominent late with a sweet-yet-woody finish. Very good, but not great.

Bottle from a guy who packed a box. Nose is toffee, vanilla, booze, fruity, slightly grape with some apple. Pour is deep brown with ruby highlights. minimal off white head. Taste is mostly booze with strong vanilla and woody tannins, but in a complimentary way, or rather, an alesmith way. The biggest complaint I have about this is that the booze dominates the base beer and I miss the subtleness of smokiness, peatiness, and caramelization from a scotch ale. Otherwise, the barrel character is very well done, alcohol is not too hot, but definitely there. Good boost

This one goes out to the two bosses - Vestergaard and Rasmussott thanks you guys. 
Pour opaque, very dark brown, with a small thin khaki head.
Aroma has plenty of dark berries, quite some bourbon, barrel, vanilla, banana, marzipan, almonds. Puhh wee this is filthy!! 
The taste is pretty sweet, but has some bitterness to it. Some heat in the throat. 
Oily n medium bodied, with a flat but tingling carb. Pretty darn delicious.

Bottle from 2005 - nr 86/223. Looks really, really good. Beer in the glass dark brown, almost black, small head. Fiery-malty aroma. Starts strong, not too alcoholic, warming, fiery, intense malty. Fine roasty notes, not too intense. Some hints of wood. Finish a bit drier, dusty, rusty, still roasty. Warming-malty finish. A masterpiece!

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Aaron. Pour is murky brown with a small tan head and decent lacing. Big toffee, raisins, figs, some caramelized sugars, light cocoa, bourbon, and nutty aroma. Taste is big cocoa, some heat, bourbon, raisins, coconut, somewhat tangy, licorice, butterscotch, and caramel with a some-sweet finish. Slick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Solid offering.

At Stephens 2nd annual Great American Beer Festival Tasting on 10/1/14. Pours very dark almond with slight circle of head. Aroma is booze sweet raison, caramel. Taste is cloyingly sweet, some fruit notes kind of berry or coconut, sharp sweet nuttiness. Way too sweet.

Bottle @ Stephens whale slaying. Thanks to nightrider for sending! Pours a dark brown appearance with a thin dark brown head. A bit smoky, dark chocolate, herbal, slightly green aroma. Dull carbonation. A little gooey mouth feel. Dark creamy caramel, burnt, slightly smoky, dark chocolate flavor. A touch boozy. Fine but doesnt blow my mind.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown mahogany color with a creamy tan head. Beautiful bourbon nose with vanilla, scotch, oak, booze. Even better flavor with tons of barrel-aged goodness, lots of bourbon and vanilla with that classic scotch ale taste. Long lingering bourbon and vanilla. So good!

"A little worried that the bourbon barreling would overpower (that was kind of the case with Speedway). Out of the bottle, mostly bourbon aroma, but oh, did it smell great after pouring. The vanilla and oak go sooo well with the chocolate and dark fruit aspects of the beer. Similar flavor, near perfection. This would be one of the best ever if it didnt look and feel a little flat - but DAMN was it good!"
This one is all about the malt....and such a good complex flavor of malt in the nose and flavor. Slightly peated, real carmel richness, but I go back to all the wonderful malt. Perfect

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2015 Tasted from bottle. Pours a dark brown with off white head. Aroma is caramel, toffee, maple syrup, dark fruit. Taste is similar to aroma thats full bodied with a sticky mouthfeel. Some alcohol burn at the end. Flavors or bourbon, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, dark fruits. Exceptional scotch ale. Up there with founder backwoods bastard as the best scotch ale Ive had. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

750 ml bottle - 2009 vintage, kindly shared by kraddel. Pours intense brown with a purple hue. Aroma is in majority defined by raisins and some madeira touches but... ouch all is covered by a layer of dust. Light body, sweet, bit watery, no carbonation. Taste is... well dusty caramel. A bit dissapointed actually...

Bottle obtained in a trade like a year ago . No idea who I have to thank , but thank you to a great trader either way ! 

2009 vintage , 156/972
pours dark, dark copper. No real head . 
Smell is straight bourbon , very intense. Some dust and madeira. 
Soft carbo , taste is madeira , sweet , some earth , bourbon and oak . 
Rather thin mouthfeel , yet intense taste . Very nice , but perhaps too boozy for the ABV
Dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma is brown sugar, honey, dark fruit, bourbon. Full bodied, sweet and boozy on the palate. Taste is dark fruits, caramel, bourbon, chocolate.

Drinking from a bomber. Ar:Bourbon, toffee,sweetness Ap:dark brown with minimal head T:Big Bourbon flavor up front with toffee, malts and maybe some chocolate P: viscous mouthfeel, with a lasting palate O: delicious beer that I was happy to have had. Just wish it wasnt so expensive. It was worth it though.

Pour out of 750 ml bottls, dark brownish black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big vanilla, dark fruit, some oak, nice bourbon, dark caramel, toffee, hints of roast, some yeasty spice. Taste is a mix of dark fruit, cocoa, nice oak, vanilla, nice oak, spice, some hints of booze, bourbon, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Sample @ RBWG Grand Tasting. Brown pour with a small tan head. Toffee chews, burnt brown toast. Rich caramel. Not much barrel character. The taste is similar. Robust burnt brown sugar and a bit of roasted malt bitterness to keep the sweet flavors in check. Soft booziness, but not overwhelming. Nice.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2016 Bottle at Olympen, march 11th 2016. Dark brown body with a small beiige head. Aroma of coffee, hazelnut, vanilla, booze and dark malt. taste is sweet and alcoholic with a strong toffee and bourbon character, dark fruit, cookies and fruit. Sticky sweet finish with apleasing lasting sweet caramel and toast aftertaste.
Color caoba oscuro. Espuma beige. aromas de bourbon, maiz, platano, regaliz, pasas, madera. Cuerpo medio-alto, inicio dulce, bourbon, manzana, que se une a la madera en un final seco. Excelente.

Pours like an impy stout. Black with a brown head. Aroma of sweet butterscotch, toffee, dark sweet fruits, sweet bourbon notes, nutty caramel and vanilla. Very nice aroma. The taste is rather sweet with notes of hazelnuts, vanilla, chocolate, dark sweet fruits, sweet bourbon, caramel and some alcohol. Very good and sweet Barley Wine! A real sipping pleasure!

Bottle split at the Manny G tasting, big thanks to Paulo, 2009 vintage, 28/06/14.
Murky chestnut/mahogany brown with thin light beige spotting and edgework that soon dissipates to nyadda.
Nose is toffee, light spice, dark malts, light bourbonic booze notes, sticky dark fruit mash, dates, prunes, brown sugar.
Taste comprises caramel, spice, fruit cake mix, dates, toffee, figs, dark malts, woody bourbon pangs.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, light alcohol in the close.
Solid BA affair, well balanced, easy to drink.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Awesome intense maltiness, some roastiness, caramelish, candy, vanilla, dark fruits, well noticeable BA wood impact with some warming whiskey in finish. Less choco than in non BA version. Sweet all the way with bittersweet finish. Huge, well balanced, interesting brew. Must try, but.. doubt that for that price I will buy it again. Maybe if it was 0.3 l bottle, but..

2009 Bottle shared at Manny G. It pours deep darkest red-brown with a small, bubbly beige head. The nose is soft, vanilla, dark fruits, roasty, berry, candy and caramel. The taste is roasty, toast, dried berry, wood, vanilla, sweet plum, jammy, booze, caramel and earth with a dry, warming finish. Medium-full body and fine carbonation. Rich and good depth. I think the aged version of regular may have been a touch better. Still very nice.

Bottle. Pours extremely dark brown with an almost brown white head. Aroma has lots of brown sugar, bourbon, brunsviger, syrup, dates, butter. Taste is dark, overripe fruits, caramel, chocolate, roasted malts, bourbon. Buttery feel, slightly high carb, nice, full body. Very nice and fruity, but not worth its high cost.

2012 reserve poured into snifter.

A - bourbon, vanilla, caramelized sugars, soft leather

App - quickly dissipating off-white head. lively carb bubbles

T - let this one warm up to room temperature before you judge--it comes alive like whoa: blueberry, chocolate, toffee, spicy bourbon (almost rye-like flavors), raisins, and a touch of vanilla. 

P - very light body considering this is a 10% beer; creamy mouthfeel, with good carb. Finishes smoothly on the vanilla note.

outstanding entry by alesmith. no doubt best in its class. now if only I could get some BA Speedway...

750ml bottle in a tulip. Pours deep brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of dark malts, some chocolate and light notes of roast, bourbon and oak, a lot of caramel and sweet malts, hints of vanilla, and some light dough and hints of bitterness. Flavor the same. Smooth texture. A cool beer, probably one of my favorites of the style.

Bottle @ Fermentoren, Århus. Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma of rich malt, caramel, bourbon, oak, vanialla, wood, little dark fruit. Flavor is malty, caramel, little dark chocolate, wood, coconut, vanilla, bourbon, some alcohol. Full body, oily mouthfeel, sweet finish with some warming alcohol. A little heavy on the bourbon, but a nice sipper. 120614

Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Very dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts,bourbon, vanilla, oak, wood, chocolate and caramel. Roasted malts, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla,wood, sweet, little dark fruit, caramel, little plume, thick, littlesticky and warming.

Bottle @ Fermentoren, Aarhus. Vintage 2012. Clear avery dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, bourbon and a little wood. Flavor is very sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish with warming alcohol. 120614

2009. A - pours dark bloody mahogany with so little head it's like negative head. S - so much booze. Scotch all up in my face. Grainy and raisins. Dark dried fruits, cherry cordials, rye. M - so light and flat. Warm but with a light tartness. Dry end. T - all the nice barrel aged goodness just toned way way down and flattened out. Graham crackers, cherry cordials, burnt sugar, brown sugar, rye, mineral water, wet oak. O - could be a great beer, but 2009 is way past it's prime.
Brown pour and aroma of smoke and peat with a tiny beige-like head, some caramel malts and taste is sweet with big alcohol bite with some faint peaty notes, 2012 bottle

Bottle at OBriens, San Diego. Dark brown cola. Medium carbonation, Flavour is brown sugar and caramel. Bourbon barrel is ideal for the scotch style ale. Woody oak and caramel. Finish is such a nice bourbon richness and fullness, like liqueur. The fizziness means the finish isnt overly sticky. Much prefer this to the base beer.

2012(?) bottle, sampled side-by-side with regular wee heavy and backwood bastard. From notes. Consider this entry more of a difference from AleSmith Wee Heavy (I wonder what the appropriate convention is for citing other ratings?). Anyway, appearance: similar in color, but somewhat darker head that dissipates quickly to no head. Aroma: rather similar, but with lots of vanilla and bourbon. The few hops that were present are now stale/old, but in a good way. More dark fruits as well. So basically more of everything except hops and toast. A bit sweeter. Palate: wow, even smoother than the original, which is impressive. Smooth and sexy with medium-full body and gentle carbonation. More raisins, plums, and just keeps getting better and better throughout the glass. I would have missed out on a lot of this if I just had 4oz I think. Either that or by 8-12 I was getting good and drunk and like everything more (though the other glasses werent empty yet, and they didnt improve as much as this one, so I suppose theres something to it). Delicious.

Pours dark red

Smell fruity, brandy

Taste sweet malty, fruity, boozy

Fuller body

Nice

750 ml Bottle of 2012 Vintage (10% ABV). Burnt brownish amber colored with a half-inch of mocha foam. Strong notes of bourbon, coconut, caramelized sugars and dark fruits in the aroma. Taste is pure caramel, malt, vanilla and bourbon with a bit of butterscotch, brown sugar and molasses around the edges. Mouthfeel is silky smooth with low carbonation and more dark sugars and toasted oak in the finish. Overall, an exquisite dessert in a glass style beer and easily one of the top Scotch Ales around.

2004 vintage 164/234

A- Pours a deep ruddy brown hue with a very small fizzy head.

S- LOTS of deep bourbon notes with dark fruit sneaking its way through.

T- The most bourbon ive ever tasted in a beer all the way through, earthy tones, undertones of dark fruit.

M- Thick with low carbonation.

D- A huge, bourbony beer that has held up well these years.

2013 bomber bought at Discount Liquor - Waukesha, WI. Pours a dark ruddish brown with a creamy tan/brown head that quickly dissipates. Rich, dark fruit, vanilla, whiskey, creamy goodness all rolled into one beautiful beer. Very well balanced, complex scotch ale. If you can find it - buy it!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wow..decandence in a bottle. So much going on, perfectly melded together in a robust, rich opulent product. Dark berries, rich dark malt, light vanilla and sticky bourbon. Good carbonation and full body for a BA beer. JUst an absolute delight. WORLD CLASS.

2012 bottle. Pours a nice murky dark reddish brown with a super tiny khaki head. Wow lots going on on the nose. Nice bourbon notes up front, vanilla and caramel, dark fruit, toasted oak, and molasses. Taste is awesome too. Sweet dates and plums, caramel, oak, toffee, a little nutty, and a nice subtle bourbon flavor. Deeeelicious. Not a trace of alcohol. Wish I could get some more of this.

Pours black with a slightly sweet aroma. The body starts very sweet with a creamy caramel taste that finishes with a strong licorice flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared @ Deans aged pale lager tasting, courtesy of deanso. Pours a dark brown beer with thin off white head on top. Aroma really has loads of bourbon, wood, sugar, caramel fudge and vanilla. Some faint dark fruits in the background, overpowered by a massive malt bill. Flavor is very sweet, barrel characters, molasses, vanilla and bourbon. Long cloying finish, very sweet. Very sugary, but sure as hell one great beer!!

Bottle at Deans aged pale lager tasting. Black pour, thin off-white head. Aroma has loads of bourbon, leather, spicy, vanilla, oak and quite some vanilla. Flavor is quite spicy, stophoest, licorice and roasted malts. Great balance, very smooth.

Bottle shared thanks to Deanso. Pours near black with a ring beige head. Aroma of strong bourbon/vanilla, caramel, milk chocolate, booze, toffee, sweet soy. Flavor is heavy sweet and moderate bitter. Full bodied with light carbonation.
Bottle @ tasting, thanks Dean. Aroma is big bourbon, some alcohol, caramel, malt, vanilla etc etc. Flavour is huge bourbon, caramel, malt. Roast, chocolate, bourbon. Stophoest. LRAB.

66cl bottle courtesy of a trade with Dennoman, thanks.
thin tan head. Bourbon aroma. Clear black pour. Lots of bourbon. Very nice

2012 bottle, pours plum amber, silky light cream hued head. nose of raisins, plums, bourbon. taste is all of the above. bourbon is most noticeable on the lingering finish. slight booze burn finishes an otherwise creamy silky full body. MOAR!!!!!!!

On tap poured into a 4oz shaker sampler glass. This starts out with a strong aroma of chocolate covered cherries and bourbon. This fades and the smell of chocolate turtles begins to take over as this mellows (chocolate, caramel, and pecans). The body of this beer is a rich, dark caramel color with an off-white head that retains well and leaves a moderate amount of lace on the glass. This has a well balanced taste of medium-high sweetness with a medium-light bitterness. This is a full bodied, thick, but smooth textured beer. This has a really soft, creamy carbonation that finishes with a roasty, nutty, chocolate note. the aftertaste is the same as eating a turtle - a bit salty and sweet. Theres a nice bourbon warmth to this one too.

2004 bottle (166/239) at the RBWG grand tasting 
Clear dark brown with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma of caramel and woody. Flavors of caramel, woody, some hot alcohols and oak 
Nice

Bottle graciously shared at RBWG grand tasting! Pours a slightly hazy copper with minimal head or lacing. Aroma and taste are both big on the barrel with a nice maltiness, brown sugar and caramel, but not crazy sweet. Age has definitely treated this beer very well.

Sampled at rbwg. Tne 10th anniversary of this beer. Bottle number 246 of 239 from 2004. Reddish dark brown. This smells really nice. Raisins and wood with bourbon. Bourbon is tasted girst and it nrings huge warming. It causes me to sit as my legs seem to fade. Raisins again. Brown sugar. This has held up so well and has not shrunk from anything. My face is numb. Awesome.

Bottle at RBWG Asheville Grand Tasting. Vintage 2004. Big thanks to Jay! Pours clear amber with a slight bubbly head. Rich malt nose, dark fruits, figs, alcohol, wood, raisins. Big sweet flavor, relaxed, lots of figs, dates, toffee, and bread. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Chewy. Sweet, warming finish, lots more ripe, semi-dark fruits, toffee, figs, raisins, toffee, brown sugars. Lovely. Decadent, nuanced. Superb.

Taster at RBWG 2014 grand tasting - thanks to springslicker! This is a 2004 bottle, number 166 of 239. Whoa. Mostly hazy sort of amber brown red orange color. Minimal off-white head. Very, very light carbonation. Bigger body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Lightly sticky. Very nice bourbon, caramel malt, scotch type characteristics. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, light nice alcohol warmth. Very impressive for a 10 year old wee heavy. Some notes of oxidization, dark fruit, dates, but still maybe one of the best beers Ive tried that was this old. Maybe just a hint of light tartness. Cool.

Pours birch beer with no head at all. Aroma is really sweet and smooth with caramel malts. Flavor is really smooth with sweet non overbearing malts and no heat from the barrel at all. There is a smooth creamy toffee light chocolate aspect as well so nice on the palate.

2013 bottle poured into a mini-snifter. Pours a clear, dark amber with a beige head of foam. The aroma has rich notes of bourbon, caramel, and toasted malt. Very sweet and boozy across the board. Medium carbonation. Big body. Really good.
Pours a purpley brown with a tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and caramel. Some vanilla. Some heat but not overpowering like others in the style. Medium body. Light carb.
Bottle shared thanks to artmcd8. Poured dark red brown with light tan film. Nice aroma of bourbon barrel dark fruit caramel. Light light carb med bod. Sweet bourbon malty goodness.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2014 2012 vintage (12/31/13). Pours a dark brown with auburn edges. Small soapy beige head, mostly lasting. Lovely aroma. Sweet and malty, clean alluring Bourbon, vanilla, light woody, caramel, bit of dark fruity, silky chocolate, complex but not perplexing, soft. Medium not quite Full body but not chewy. Soft. Smooth, rounded, and velvety. Amazing Finish has some initial pleasant alcohol warmth that quickly gives was to sublet vanilla and some malty sweetness. Phenomenal.

Very sweet, very malty, caramel, bourbon, toasty/roasty, vanilla, dark fruit. 
Taste is similar, very strong, bold flavor. Creamy, malty, bourbon, roasty, sweet dark fruit. A bit of a bourbon, vanilla, turning to chocolate, bitter finish.
Possibly a little too sweet at times, but it is  a sipping beer Id say, so slowly enjoy it and the sweetness is not as strong.
Bold and beautiful.

Bachelor party scotch ale tasting. 750 mL bottle from the brewery, served in a stem glass alongside the original. Pours deep chestnut with a small tan head that fades to a thin remnant. The nose has bourbon, vanilla, oak, molasses, brown sugar, molasses and subtle hints of earth and hops. The flavour is moderately sweet with vanilla, bourbon and molasses. It develops slight herbal hoppy notes towards the finish, which is long and malty, with vanilla and molasses. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall this is an amazing and truly exceptional beer. The most complex, elegant scotch ale on the market. Elegant, perfect, balanced, complex. Wow. 2013-07-25
Bottle...Pour is dark black with a very thin head..Nose is nice bourbon, vanilla, spice, oak, raisin, fudge...Taste is fudge, vanilla, spice, oak, nice toffee and burnt caramels.

Hmmm. Deep, slightly reddish brown, foam dusting on the surface. Bourbon like barrel aging notes, ie wood, cherry, etc, but honestly not particularly striking. Flavor is nutty plus cherry plus wood plus alcohol. Again, i see the effort but nothing particularly noteworthy. Not bad, but quite disappointing.
2012 bottle thanks to jhogan. Scotish malt and a touch of bourbon. Very balanced. Really good, nothing stands out, but nothing wrong with it.

Aged 3 years (2010 vintage): This awesome concoction of yumminess is dark brown in color with a small, medium-brown colored head, a little thin in appearance. The aroma is nice and very soft, almost reminiscent of cherries. It smells much like a thinned out (or aged) Wee Heavy with some cherries sticking their heads out from beneath the surface. A good level of potent alcohol is present, but its not overpowering. The flavor will knock your socks off. Its sweet and fruity with an almost tart character. Its amazingly enjoyable, really super fruity, but with some respectable hair on its chest. Its quite delicious with definite currants, cherries, and alcohol flavors, with some peat character surfacing after a while. It ends with a glorious, tart, fruity finish. This is fantastic.

pours very dark brown with a small light beige head, some retention and lacing. burnt caramel, raisins, bananas - abusive use and/or extended BA period in bourbon barrels, cherries, nice fruitiness. sweetness. moderate carbonation, medium to full body - oily and almost syrupy, grassy-peppery and boozy-bourbony finish. quite tasty and good but sort of fails at rending a more rounded and complex product than the non-ba version.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours very deep burgundy with low beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of caramel, malt, bourbon. Taste is of caramel, malt, bourbon, sugar, alcohol, slight nuts. Palate: Full bodied. Sticky texture. Overall: Pretty good. Not too cloying. Slightly boozy.

Bottle (750 ml). Thanks to vissai for this one! Dark brown with reddish reflects, medium beige head and some lacing. Aroma is of toffee, burnt caramel, bourbon, wood, sweetness notes, dark fruits and vanilla. Taste is moderately sweet with burnt caramel, toffee, bourbon, vanilla, oak and dark fruits notes. Medium to full body. Moderate carbonation. Very complex. Not too sweet or cloying. Good use of the barrels. Drinkable for a bourbon barrel aged Wee Heavy. AleSmith are among the best (if not the best) to aged this kind of big beers in barrels. Solid stuff!

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2014 Bottle: Thanks, Kevin! Deep ruby red with brown tints; opaque body with translucent edges and a light-tan cap that fades quickly with nothing left behind. Aroma is deep, syrupy dark fruit sweetness, huge bourbon, oak, brown sugar, light cocoa powder. Taste is even bigger on the bourbon and oak flavors; slightly hot. Syrupy, sweet prune-like fruits, anise, licorice, burnt toffee. Its both very sweet and very boozy, and they dont necessarily balance each other perfectly. Could pass for a barrel aged barley wine. Pretty good, but a little over the top.
Dark brown color. Big creamy nose with bourbon, caramel, dark plums, boozy, but very enjoyable. A touch sweet. Very velvety smooth mouth. Full body. Delicate. Amazing beer

Bottle from Jeff. Thanks a million! Poured to snifter/tulip thingy deep dark brown with hints of reddish amber at the edges. Half finger caramel colored head that recedes shortly thereafter. Aroma of big biscuit, lots of nuttiness, toffee, vanilla, oak, whiskey booze. Oh man. Flavor is big whiskey and nuttiness with an excellent sweet-bitter balance. Finishes with a nice toffee vanilla caramel sweetness that lingers. Just a bit of heat on the way down. Thick but carbonation is adequate. So glad I got to try it finally. Awesome BA beer, though I might a really like the regular version a tad better. Alesmith continues to impress.

PS-This went amazingly with a chunk of cheddar cheese!

Bottle through trade huge thanks for sending this my way! Bottle from 2012 release gold print on the bottle no numbers or date. Pour has a very dark cola brown color and a thin coating of dark tan head. Aroma has lots of juicy bourbon barrel, rich malt, vanilla, brown sugar, mild roast, and a hit of chocolate like the regular release. Mouth feel is a solid medium and there is low side carbonation but it is carbonated. Flavor is extremely rich, deep malt, mild roast, lovely bourbon barrels, vanilla, mild sweetness, and a hit of custard on the finish. Absolutely tremendous beer, big and full of brut while the barrels round out the edges and make the flavors transition so well. First WOW beer in a while!

Bottle: &nbsp Dark murky brown with deep reddish hues, huge rocky beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Dark pitted fruit nose, slight peat, a little heat. &nbsp Bready, sweet, with figs and dates running around as well. &nbsp On the 

tongue its a bit more fruity. &nbsp Bready, peaty, noticeable bourbon and barrel aging on the tongue. &nbsp Smooth, warming, and simply delicious! &nbsp Lots of peat and dark pitted fruit, as well as a good amount of warming. &nbsp Body 

and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Its been 9 years since I have had an Alesmith Wee Heavy, and I may prefer the original as the barrel aging does seem to overshadow some of the subtle aspects of the original beer. &nbsp Body and 

mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp Finishes warming, loads of bourbon, some peat, campfire, and dark pitted fruit. &nbsp Certainly more warming/alcoholic than the original. &nbsp Very good, but its hard to beat the original. &nbsp 

Huge thanks to mashmasterfor the opportunity to try this one!

Poured from a 750 cc bottle. Pours dark-brown black. Tan head with nice lacing. Aroma is out of this world rich sweet malts, dark cherry, chocolate, vanilla, and oaky bourbon. Flavour delivers on the aroma. The bourbon barrel aging manages to improve one of the best Scotch Ales ever brewed.

750 ml bottle shared by ??? at tasting. Pours dark mahageny with a small head that lingers a bit. Aroma is very intense. Lots of oak, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, booze, and coconut. Very intense barrel flavors in the taste. Bourbon, vanilla, and coconut mostly with some light caramel. Medium body with a sticky and syrupy mouthfeel. A pretty intense beer that was great to sip on. Would be hard to drink more than a sample.

Courtesy of Shane. Many thanks. Reviewed from notes.

A: Very dark mahogany that swallows the light and makes this seem still and serene. Fluffy, bubbly head fades to a drifting pond. Good legs.

N: Wow. Caramel and vanilla, oak and coconut hit me from a few feet away. Bourbon soaked cherries. Some brown sugar and clover. Coriander.

T: Smoked sweetness and tons of toffee. Lots of it. Bitterness seems nonexistent, but this never risks becoming cloying. 

M: Lots of alcohol. Stick and medium bodied.

O: This is one of my favorite beers, because this is always what I hope a BA Barleywine is going to taste like, even though its not one. Gotta hand it to Alesmith, they do barrel aging right.

Bottle from Larry, nice ruby brown pour with a tan head. Aromas of malt, light nutty notes, vanilla and caramel. Taste is booze up front, caramel, roasted sweet malt, probably best wee heavy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

June 14, 2013 - bottle shared by Brandon.  Dark brown pour with some head that faded quickly.  Aroma was bourbon, wood, vanilla and malt.  Taste was consistent with aroma with a nice alcohol finish.  Barrel aging did this well.

2009 bottle. Cloudy black, rather muddy, with lace. Nose of bourbon, vanilla, toffee, chocolate, cola, cherries. Sweet, fruity, tangy flavor, with cherries, bourbon, big vanilla. Light carbonation and creamy, smooth. A big beer with lot of barrel. Very nice, but in small servings.
Bottle shared by a friend. Pours a dark cherry brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of bourbon, cherry and caramel. Malty flavor with bourbon and cherry before a brandy finish.

Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is vanilla, cashews, oak, toast, and bourbon. Taste is vanilla, oak, caramel, mixed nuts, chewy malt, and some bourbon. This beer is absolutely fucking fantastic! Cheers to ParkerDaniels for this one!
Started off a little too cold but as it warmed those great sweet smokey flavors came out and proved what a wonderful Ale this is.
Dark brown pour at brew pub. Nose is of scotch, bourbon, vanilla and toffee. Velvet smooth bourbon taste with caramel and hints of vanilla. Phenominal.

Pours a dark brown with nice tan head that leaves a nice lacing around the glass.  Aromas of cherries, toffee followed by flavors of cherries, toffee, vanilla and bourbon as the finish.  This is a very well balanced beer.
Poured on tap at Alesmith. Dark brown with mild head. Smells of bourbon, dark sugars with a delicate booziness. Complex flavors with a lingering finish. Worth a try when available.
On tap in SD. Flavor is rich and malty with dark fruit, oak, vanilla, bourbon, toffee, a hint of licorice and a light orange.

Bottle, 04/22/2013, 2012 release. Pours dark brown, creamy tan head fades to a nice crema on the surface, thick sticky lacing. Aroma is brown sugar, molasses, fruity dark malts, hints of berries, butterscotch, sharp yet well integrated spicy bourbon, vanilla. Taste is caramel, raisin, licorice, brown sugar molasses, lightly fruity hops, bourbon clearly pleasant and tasty, blends well. Palate is thick, creamy, typical of these big Alesmith brews. Very nice, top notch BA treatment.

On tap at Alesmith.  
Aroma: big toffee and caramel, lots of toast and biscuit maltiness, some sweetness, definitely rich, nice notes of spirits and oak.
Appearance: pours mahogany, slight haze, khaki head lasts for a short time and leaves a bit of lacing.
Taste: decadent dark sugars - lots of caramel, molasses, and toffee.  Rich and filling without being overly sweet.  Bitterness from hops and alcohol is low, just enough to balance the malt charge.  Dark fruits, some nice barrel character and spirits, very well integrated and balanced.
Palate: full body, low-medium carbonation, very smooth.
Overall: a really great brew, glad I had a chance to try it.

Thanks for the share Jordan, this brew was awesome! The body had a fantastic, deep ruby red hue to it with a soft toffee head. Aromas revealed bourbon, cherries, toffee, light toast and perhaps marshmallows. The taste had a brilliant buttery-malt quality to it while mellow caramel and bourbon-oak undertones calm the palate down. This stuff is serious, to finally try it was a rare moment Ill always remember.

This was amazing! Free beer week prize from StefanSD! Thanks a ton! Nose is big ass bourbon notes with some vanilla, caramel, toffee, coconut, light fruitiness, and watermelon rind. Pour is almost black with a faint tan head. Flavors match up. Big, bold, full of bourbon but not overpowering the base beer. Great balance and execution here. Alesmith does it again. Wow!

2012. Pours a dark brown with a small amount of bubbles. The head is beige and dissipates relatively quickly. Nice enough lacing though. Aroma is a well blended mix of bourbon notes and the wonderful flavors of the base beer. Theres vanilla, oak, bourbon and a bit of booze mixed into molasses, caramel, fresh dough, toasty malt sugars and all sorts of other warm, friendly flavors. Taste is sweet and warm. Its a lovely beer. I realize that Im sorta repeating myself here, but the rich malt flavor of the base beer is impeccably blended into the bourbon barrel flavors. Alesmith is one of the very best at barrel aging, and it very much shows in this beer. Feel is smooth and full. Never gets too sticky or boozey. This is just a phenomenal beer. On a sidenote, I dont think it will get any better with age. This beer is drinking wonderfully, right now.

Aroma: reminds me of Westy12 - amazing caramel and bourbon!
Appearance: beautiful light brown colored pour from 750ml bottle
Taste: heavenly
Palate: creamy and smooth finish
Overall: probably the best scotch ales Ive ever enjoyed!!
DArk and inviting. HUGE scotch ale made huger with some nice oak and vanilla.

15 mar 2013, bottle. Dark brown. Nose is  huge bourbon. Med body and moderately fizzy. Gorgeous bourbon, maple syrup, faint molasses, maybe some bacon. Wow! Awesome!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head.  Nose is bourbon, vanilla, molasses, wood, malt.  Flavor is bourbon, wood, caramel, vanilla, molasses.  Thick chewy mouthfeel.  Having a hard time understanding why this one is still on the shelves in San Diego.

Wow this bad boy was so very very d e l i c i o u s! Thank you bird machine. Dark creamy sweet. Rich toffee caramelwood silght vanilla. Similar to Goose Island but better. One of the best beers I have ever had.

Bottle - huge thanks to bird_machine for bringing this to a share! Pours clear dark brown with a medium brown creamy head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is very rich, almost decadent, with notes of caramel, vanilla, molasses, bourbon, toffee. Flavor is the same, medium sweet and only lightly warming. This is a damn nice beer.

Bottle @ a recent bottle share...  Poured dark brown with some reddish tones and thin forming, khaki head.  What an unbelievable treat.  Big, lushish bourbon and whiskey-soaked wood tones here.  Caramel sweetness and malt sweetness intertwined with dark fruits and ale yeast esters.  Complex yet right on point.  Also notes of cocoa with added whiskey cocktail tones.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with fast fading but big tan head. Aroma if roasted wood and sweet caramel. Taste is very thick smooth burnt bourbon toffee. Super tasty beer

Bottle for HopMasterFlex. Pours hazy rich dark brown with very small tan head. Aromas of bourbon,  vanilla, molasses, wood, bit of dark fruit, and loads of sweet malts. Flavors bourbon, wood, sweet caramel, vanilla, molasses, chewy thick malts, and touch of dark fruit. Mouthfeel is a little syrupy and carbonation is low, but really works here. Yeah this was really good. Drank almost the whole bottle myself.

Bottle thanks to Fitz! Pours deep brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is bourbony, plenty sweet with a nice woody and earthy note, nice fruitiness. Flavor is also very bourbon forward, sweet and caramely with plenty of fruit and some cherry. Medium to full body and a soft carbonation. Nice beer!

750 ml. 2009 bottle.  Thanks Mike!  Pours dark brown with a small biege head.  Aroma of malt, fruit, caramel, and bourbon.  Taste is sweet malt, cherries, raisins, chocolate, bourbon, and wood.  Very, very good!

2009 thanks Denise

Dark brown pour with no head, almost completely flat.  Smell of bourbon, with a mild whisky , molasses and warm after taste.
2009 vintage. Boozy, caramel, bourbon, a touch of sweetness, mild smoke, ends slightly watery. Complexity at every turn. Really good.

2009 Bottle thanks to Ronnie. Pour is dark, dark red. Head is moderate but persistent. Malt, bourbon, tobacco on the nose. Tastes much better than non BA Wee Heavy.. vanilla, bourbon, cherry. Almost tasted like an after dinner drink. One of the best scotch ales. One of the best opening drinks to any session.

Sample, olive bottle, 750 ml, bottle 900 of 972; eye: black, opaque, no effervescence, no head, no lacing; nose: woody, bourbon, malt, anise, dark fruits, light chocolate, alcohol, light peat; mouth: woody, bourbon, malt, anise, dark fruits, light chocolate, alcohol, light scotch, hops, caramel, finale in bourbon with woody presence, medium-full body, not much carbonation, lightly bitter, mildly sweet, liqueur-like texture texture; overall: quite fine
 
FRANÇAIS
 
Échantillon, bouteille olive, 750 ml, bouteille 900 de 972; il : noire, opaque, pas deffervescence, pas de mousse, pas de dentelle; nez : boisé, bourbon, malt, anis, fruits noirs, léger chocolat, alcool, léger tourbe; bouche : boisé, bourbon, malt, anis, fruits noirs, léger chocolat, alcool, léger scotch, houblon, caramel, finale en bourbon avec présence boisée, corps moyen-corsé, peu carbonatée, légèrement amère, moyennement sucrée, texture liquoreuse; en résumé : bien bon

Bottle compliments of Alan with some other heads. Pours a deep, rich brown color with sticky beige head and lacing. Notes of mollases, syrup, oak, bourbon, raisins, dark pitted fruit, and light chocolate. Full mouth with little carbonation. The finish is long lasting and malt sticky on the palate. Still had some heat for being a few years old. Very impressive Scotch.

A dark brown ale with a thin mocha head. In aroma, peaty caramel malt with molasses, vanilla, light aniseed, and alcohol. In mouth, a dryish and sweet darj fruit malt with molasses,intense alcohol, aniseed, quite nice. Tasted with GRM, Puskinwow, Boutip, Ian, Mike on Sept. 7 2012.

750 ml. bottle. It pours a dark brown color and almost still with just a thin ring of foam that slowly builds around the edges. The aroma jumps out with intense bourbon wood, vanilla, alcohol, raisins, molasses and nuts. The flavor is similar with more dark fruit up front, mostly raisins and figs with some bourbon alcohol coming in later with intense vanilla and wood in the finish. The carbonation is lacking in this one with just a hint to keep it from being completely flat, but the flavors are rich enough for it not to distract. Its obviously pretty full bodied, but not too syrupy by any means. A very good beer, but Im not sure it was worth the effort to track it down. Id probably rather have an Angels Share.

Bomber tnx to Greg. Pours dark brown with a small tanned head. Aroma is sweet raisins vanilla malty toasted dill fruity toasted. Flavor is sweet velvety smooth raisins malty toasted bready nutty not as bitter as the ordinary a bit astringent. Finishes malty sweet slightly bitter. Good balance with all parts, very drinkable.

Bottle (2009 vintage): Poured a clear medium brown color ale with a medium size off-white foamy head with some retention and some lacing. Aroma of sweet malt with light toffee notes and light butterscotch and some wood with a light whiskey finish. Taste is also a good mix between balanced notes of butterscotch and caramel with some notes of wood and whiskey and light residuals sugar notes. I though the body was a bit thin for the style with medium carbonation.

750 ml bottle, #900 from 2009. Dark brown with a light off white head. Prune, anise, peat, alcohol/scotch, earthy wood, some butterscotch. Moderate carbonation, full body, fruity and sweet, incredibly dry, more scotch and peat with hints of tannin, pepper, and vanilla. On the one hand this is delicious; on the other it may benefit from another year or so to meld and balance out - either way this is an incredible beer.

A-- Poured a deep, dark ruby brown color. Very little head with this and not a lot of carbonation. No lacing and some visible ABV to this as quite syrupy. 

S-- Insane! Buttered vanilla, buttered Toffee and bourbon. Just a very warming smell. Bourbon was pretty reserved though. Still best aspect of this was the nose. 

T-- Really buttery taste to this. Thick vanilla toffee taste. 

M-- Barrel really disappeared in the mouth. Really more about toffee and vanilla. Was a little sweet and syrupy. Very little carbonation and some noticeable alcohol to this. 

O-- Might be at its peak. Very well done for the style but seems to get forgotten because it is a Wee Heavy and not a Stout. Look and nose were excellent but the mouth dropped off a lot.

Bottle. 2009 vintage. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty woody caramel and dark fruit aroma. Sweetish malty woody caramel toffee and dark fruit flavor. Has a sweetish malty woody caramel and dark fruit finish.
2009 vintage.  Brown pour and aroma of smoke and peat, some caramel malts and taste is sweet with some alchool bite.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle, 2009 vintage #892, shared by badnewsbeers. Deep ruddy orange-red-brown body, thin cream to beige head. Nose is a thick swirl of caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol; prickly, sweet, and woody. Dry, slippery, leathery body. Rich, complex, warming yet soft with lingering alcohol notes.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!

Vintage 2006
Bottle 246 / 254

A: Dark chestnut brown hued, with an 1/8" of brown head that leaves some decent lacing on the glass.

S: Aromas of smoke, peat, caramels, and a hint of the aging process, but not in any sort of negative way.

T: What a great beer. Its smoky and malty, with a myriad of flavors blending together very gracefully. This Scotch ale has really mellowed with age, as its so effortless to consume and enjoy. Its slightly sweet and has hints of liquor, but its not cloying or hot. Kudos to Alesmith - this is an exceptional beer.

M: Buttery, creamy and smooth on the palate. There is still a healthy level of carbonation present, but this beer has a silky smooth consistency about it.

D: A very enjoyable experience. If you are fortunate enough to happen across this brew, you will most certainly enjoy it.

Pours a dark brown with low to medium head into a chalice. Smells like a grape blowpop. Taste is sweet with some grape and soy and a little chocolate subtle ness. Mouthfeel is highly carbonated and full bodied.  Love this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2012 2009 bottle.  Deep murky brown, thin light tan head.  Almost black, much darker than the regular version.  Rich sweetness, plum, raisin, dried dark fruit, heavy bourbon flavors, alcohol warmth, oak, a bit of chocolate, and molasses.  Thick mouth feel.  This is very delicious and decadent.  I love it.

Cask at Alesmith Early may 2012.  Wee Heavy with bourbon soaked oak chips:  Pours a reddish brown, slightly cloudy, with a bubbly light beige head.  Sweet malts, toffee, dried dark fruit, prune, raisin, oak, light vanilla, and a touch of bourbon note.  A nice beer, but I like the bourbon barrel aged version quite a bit better.  Total rating 3.9

Bottle shared at Palate Rapist tasting. 09 562/972. Big thanks to Phil for sharing this bottle. This was still a little hot and the bourbon flavor was everywhere, in the flavor and aroma. Very much a sipping a beer. Tasty to say the least.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 2009 vintage, bottle #160/972, split with manuchampions and uhlan. Pours an opaque dark mahogany / brown with almost no head. Aroma of prunes / dates, liqueur, some wood & bourbon notes, but not much scotch whiskey - ultra complex nose. Flavour is no less complex with liqueur-coated dark dried fruits, wood barrels, bourbon and a little scotch. Not much of a boozy burn. Extremely rich and complex - the barrel aging done to perfection, though about on par with the regular. It has fewer of the scotch qualities but more wood than the original Wee Heavy. I slightly prefer the original; however, this was most fantastic.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2012 2009 vintage, bottle 685/972, courtesy of stefanje for my 5000th rating. Thanks! Shared at the Baltimore Irish Hannukah Gathering, 3/17/12. Pours a clear dark red color with nearly no head. Aroma of whisky, soy, toffee, roasted malts, coconut, caramel. The taste is toffee, whisky, wood, caramel, chocolate, leafy hops, coconut, bitter finish. Full bodied.  Nice.
Thanks HallingHansen. Pours clear brown with a small head. Aroma is roasted malt, bourbon, vanilla and dark fruit. Flavour is roasted caramel, bourbon, vanilla, raisin, plum and toffee.

At HallingHansen Grand Tasting, thanks for sharing. Vintage 2009. Pours a clear and brown beer with no head. The aroma is malt, caramel, wood, vanilla, fruit, dried fruit and alcohol. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a really good beer.
Bottle 2009 version. Trade from Sean9689, thanks man. Mud brown body with a small head. Aroma is bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak. Flavor is caramel, bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit.

Hazy chestnut colour with a small off-white head. Aroma of malt and caramel with hints of dried fruit and oak. Very sweet caramel and toffee flavour with a hint of brown sugar, and some hot alcohol. The sweetness is somewhat balanced by tannins in this version of the wee heavy

Bottle shared by hallinghansen. It pours hazy dark reddish brown with a medium off white head. Heavy caramelish and toffee like aroma with notes vanilla and oak. The flavour is sweet caramelish with a bourbon kick that has notes of vanilla and oak. Long sweet toasted finsish. Thanks Jacob!
Pours brown/black with tan head.  Raisin and brown sugar nose, fusel and chocolate.  Chocolate notes, caramel, sweet and super solid.  Dry, simple and tasty

1300th rating. 2006 bottle from Daniel at November tasting. Pours a murky dark brown with paperthin beige head that diminishes quickly to nothing. The aroma is a sweet malt vanilla and oak. Thin mouthfeel with a sweet vanilla and nice lingering bitter finish. Wow did this beer hold up well, a very impressive scotch ale from Alesmith.
2009 bottle from Bill at November tasting. Pours a dark brown and ruby hue with a small off white head. The aroma is oak and bourbon. Medium mouthfeel with a sweet finish. Easy to drink, very impressive.

750 ml bottle from lushawn as a wedding gift- thanks, Shawn! Bottle #552/972. 2009 vintage. Those facts were apparently written in ballpoint pen. This is the last of the four bottles Shawn gave us for the wedding, sadly. But its a big one! Pours a deep, dark brown color, hazy and opaque in the center but clear amber on the edges, with almost no head, just a small brown ring. Aroma of bourbon, caramel, vanilla, and oak make their way through the complex Wee Heavy base of dark and dried fruits, toasted, dark, and sweet malts, and some of that Scotchy, peaty earthiness. The flavor actually shows more of the dark fruits than the nose, along with peat, caramel and toasted malts, chocolate, oak, and as it warms more bourbon, vanilla, and toffee. Medium-bodied, definitely thinner than the Wee Heavy, with low carbonation and a rich, fruity mouthfeel that becomes sweeter and stickier on the finish. Really awesome BA version of one of my favorite Wee Heavy beers. AleSmith knows how to do barrels, thats for sure.

(750ml bottle from Dak.  09 bottle #84/972).  Pours dark brown-cola color. No head.  Aroma is mostly bourbon vanilla caramel. Taste is sweet with more vanilla, and big coconut.  Sticky mouthfeel with a touch of heat. Really tasty.  Mostly barrel.

Bottle #844/972 from 2009.  Aroma has notes of bourbon, caramel malts, oak, vanilla, dark dried fruits and a touch of smoke and peat.  Very dark brown hue that sits almost black in the glass.  Small off-white foamy (almost fizzy) head that almost fully diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is very sweet.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall another bourbon bomb but not as offensive as most.  The flavors blended well and the bourbon was smooth and well integrated.  A good one and I can see why its highly rated.

Bottle, 1000th rating ;) Oily brown pour, no head. Aroma of bourbon, tons of molasses, really picking up a lot of oak notes, pretty straightforward barrel-aged malt bomb. Taste is sweet, nice bourbon, vanilla oak notes, light molasses. Palate is almost completely flat, not too heavy bodied or cloying though, okay sipper.
Bottle 548/900 of 09  Pours caramel brown with no head. Sweet vanilla bourbon nose. flavor was big and rich with sweet bourbon, vanilla, oak and a bit of caramel with a slightly sweet and dry finish.

Tap @ Taproom.  Pours dark brown with little to no head.  Aroma is sweet; bourbon, roasted malt, vanilla, some chocolate.  Flavor is similar; predominately bourbon, but generally very sweet.  Alcohol is clearly present, but not overwhelming at all.  Very roasty.  Delicious.

2009 #123/972: Pours dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Smells of peated malt, cognac, vanilla, dry oak, some spicy undertones.  Tastes of molasses, cognac, spicy, some smoky elements with a sweet, cloying finish.  Very enjoyable and full bodied.

Bottle split with James, Pat, Andrew, and Bobby. End of the night, very impaired. hard to remember but i know i liked it. dark brown pour with slight to no head. aroma is mollasses, brown sugar, and some nice oak. Taste is very smooth, malt presence is very sweet but not heavy. oak plays very well with the clean palate and makes it incredibly rounded. Good beer wish i could have another.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2012 Sampled at the DC Ratebeer Gathering.  Bottle number 39 of 222 from the 2005 vintage sampled in October 2011.  Pours a transparent, mahogany amber with one ring of spitty, beige head.  Nice brandy aroma, boozy, tropical fruit, rum, caramel, light wood, coconut.  Flavor is sweet, caramel, brandy, apples, maple, tropical fruit, spiced rum.  Full bodied, sweet, boozy finish.  Still a touch hot.  Really nice though.  8-3-9-3-16  ***** Re-rate, 2004 bottle sampled in June 2012.  750ml bottle pours a root beer brown with some clumpy white head.  Nose is awesome, bourbon, sour mash, whiskey, leather, oranges, brown sugar, some light salinity like a shucked oyster, port, rootbeer.  Flavor is sweet, candied orange peel, caramel, port, sherry, toasted bread, mint, herbs.  Medium bodied, herbal finish.  Has aged great.  Not one bit hot.  8-4-8-5-16

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2011 Bottle (2009) 548/900 or something like that... Sweet vanilla bourbon nose as soon as you popped it..  Pours a viscous black.... no head,  low carbonation... Oily.....Taste is sweet bourbon, mossy, malty notes... I enjoy the regular wee heavy much more... Medium body, little stickyness. Overall another good beer from Alesmith, but I like the regular version

Bottle. [thanks after4ever][vintage 2006]
Pours dark red-black with a small, staying, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is dry, chocolate, leather, cellar, liqourice, vanilla, oak. Medium carbonation, fat creamy palate. Flavour is sweet, fat sugary, oak, caramel, vinious, caramel, chocolate, roasted malts and quite dry. Very balanced use of the barrel. The original and this is quite different beasts though - both exceptional.

Sampled at GTs birthday tasting. 2005 vintage, thanks to Ryan for this one. Brown pour with no head. Nose holds tons of bourbon, vanilla, and caramel. The flavor brings forth molasses, chocolate, caramel, vanilla, wood, and cream. Also quite spicy. Slick and oily mouthfeel. Quite nice.

2005 vintage- thanks Ryan. Deep foreboding brown color with not too much in the form of a head. Massive bourbon notes, caramel, vanilla, and pleasantly well integrated booze. The flavor holds more massive vanilla booze notes, caramel, and sweet toffee. Uber thick and rich palate, with sweet hotness and no carbonation. Very very mild oxidation to the point of little detraction. Nice one.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2015 2005 Bottle shared by Ryan and again a 2015 bottle at home.  Pours clear tawny with a medium, fizzy beige head, medium retention with spare lacing.  Aroma is cognac, brown sugar, caramel and toffee, dates and moderate alcohol.  Flavor is sweet Bourbon, lightly spicy, dates and brown sugar, vanilla and oak with a sweet palate and a drying finish.  Full body, high warmth, and medium carbonation.

75cl, Vintage 2009, bottle 359/972 (hand-written), at 9.5%Vol, exclusive American brew, thx to Wimenels!, complex Scotch, sweet/woody and slightly smoked/alcoholic, not too heavy, yet balanced, clear, nearly no head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Thanks to Jason for sharing. 2009 vintage. 750ml bottle poured into wine glass (not sure of the # on the bottle).

A - Pours a mirky/muddy brown, small amount of off-white head, some bubbles here and there on top.

S - Sweet dark fruits, bourbon, oak, caramel, vanilla.

T - Sweet caramels, oak, smooth bourbon note. The bourbon is really nice and smooth, which is nice considering this is a recent release. 

M - Medium, light carbonation, smooth and creamy.
