D - Really enjoyed this one and was glad to try it. I would still like to try an older vintage, but I hear theyre becoming oxidized. Def would try this one again!

2006 Vintage. Aroma is wood, vanilla, bourbon and caramel. Taste is kind of tart, a little off. Finish is perfect and dry, very woody with lots of vanilla and bourbon notes. Finish lingers. Bottle may have been past its prime, nonetheless a very tasty and incredible beer.

Bottle thanks to fletchfighters. Pours a very dark brown with smallish tan coloured head. Sweet aromas of malt, dark fruits and port wine. A little vanilla from the barrels and a hint of sourness. Good stuff. Flavours a syrupy sweet with a little of the port fruitiness. Not picking up heaps from the barell. Lots of alcohol on the finish, Syrupy mouthfeel.

2009 bottle thanks to Westcoastersd. This one was a long time coming. Thick, oily beer with low carbonation and lots of smooth, malty flavors and aromas. Vanilla, caramel, smoke, dried fruit, brown sugar, cola... This almost crosses the line into freaky dessert wine territory. Awesome stuff.

750ml, gold-foiled bottle from the 2009 release #91/972 thanks to my good buddy peteinsd. thanks, peter! pours a deep, russet-brown with a razor thin, light beige head that develops smooth retention around the edges and leaves sticky rings of lace. aroma is absolutely wonderful with huge notes of sticky caramel, pralines, and molasses-covered raisins and dates with beautiful elements of wet oak, spiced bourbon, vanilla, and roast with subtle hints of cocoa, leafy earth, and smoked malts as it warms. flavor is spectacular as well with a marvelous balance of sweet oak, vanilla, and rich bourbon with smooth, smokey malts, toffee pralines, and chocolate backed by hints of earthy hops, vinous fruits, fig newton cookies, and dry scotch. palate is full bodied with light carbonation and a long, dry, slightly sweet and slightly smokey finish. overall, another fantastic brew from alesmith. damn, these guys really know how to do barrel aging right.

Pours a deep purple brown, light spotty lacing .. . figs, barrel, molasses, light tar .. . amazingly smooth, but not quite at its peak- could go for a few more years.. . happy to have tried another barreled alesmith, .. sex? no thanks im dead..

Bottle generously shared by GT2, thanks! Very dark brown, very reluctant large bubble tan head. Aroma of vanilla, driftwood, brandies chocolate.  Taste is vanilla, chocolate liquer, brandy. Barrel is not overwhelming, and I think adds to the flavor.

Bottle shared by MrPickles...thanks Andy! - Pours dark brown with next to no head. Hot as hell on the nose, and you really cant get a lot else. Taste is fantastic, with smooth vanilla, chocolate, caramel--kind of like an ice cream sundae. Light roast on the finish. Smooth as hell and thick, with enough carbonation to make it interesting. Wow--taken by surprise on this one.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Had two different vintages 09 and 06 side-by-side at a private tasting I put together.  750 ml bottles.  

09 - Pours black with tan bubbles in lieu of head.  Nose is of bourbon, toffee, roast malt and little peat.  Taste is of bourbon, chocolate, toffee and roast malt.  Mouthfeel is medium-thick and creamy with alcohol noticeable.  

06 - Pour dark brown with no head.  Nose had weaker aromas, especially the bourbon had faded.  Tastes were not as bold or rich.  Mouthfeel had thinned out somewhat.

Overall, the consensus was that the 09 was better, or in better shape, in comparison.

2009 bottle generously shared during the RBSG grand tasting. Pours a dark cola. Aroma is massively boozy. Notes of marshmallow fluff and toffee overwhelmed by harsh alcohol. Flavor is less harsh and reminds me a bit of what I love from the regular Wee Heavy: notes of rum, caramelized sugar, and toffee. Nice flavor notes are somewhat ruined by a syrupy booze finish. Some nice rum and caramel notes in the finish are masked by harsh alcohol burn, and the sweetness itself goes over the top. I know Im in the minority, but for me this is a prime example of barrel aging ruining a perfectly phenomenal beer. I mean, I love Alesmith Wee Heavy. This is just way too sweet, syrupy, and boozy.

2009 Bottle at RBSG Grand Tasting. Pours brown with a beige head. Sweet malty aroma with woody and bourbon notes and a light malty sweetness. Very smooth and refined. Sweet malt, wood, bourbon, light peat. Very well balanced. Awesome.

This poured a murky darker brown color with a very small beige head. Aroma was lots of oak and bourbon, some caramel and toffee too as welll as some chocolate. Flavor is silky smooth bourbon, taking away a bit from the underlying scotch peaty notes,  but the flavors do blend very well together, some of the toffee and caramel are there but barely.
Bottle shared by Mikey. Pours dark brown. Nose/taste of toffee, oak, scotch, peat, cocoa and brown sugar. Some hints of port wine. Full body.

2009 vintage, bottle #554 of 972.  750 ml bottle picked up for me at the brewery on release day in January 2011 by joetheyounger and Pat ($25).  Pours a nice brown-garnet hue, but even a vigorous pour produces almost no head.  Aroma of bourbon, butterscotch, earthy-peaty malts (lightly smoky), vanilla, light chocolate, and molasses.  Flavor is wonderfully complex with peaty-smoky malts, notable bourbon, vanilla, candied cherry, port wine, rich cocoa, maple syrup, etc...its simply a wonderful experience in the mouth.  Nicely sweet but far from cloying.  Soft and smooth on the palate.  An excellent beer.  (299, 573)

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2011 Bottle shared with Andrew, Pat, Dallas and Bobby. Last beer of the night after about 5 Dark Lords its tough to remember this guy clearly. Pours a murky brown body with some sediment and nice tan lacing. Aroma is sweet molasses, light vanilla, roast and cocoa. Mouthfeel is thin to medium with notes of roasted caramel, toffee, molasses, vanilla bean, creamy cocoa, tobacco, and some oak in the background.

A very nice vanilla, chocolate, rich toffee, and caramel aroma emanates from this rusty concoction that is topped with a lovely creme head.  The nose is rather complex offering even more subtle pleasures such as a light coffee, oak, raisins, and plums.  As it slips down my throat, the beer opens up and gives bold flavors of bourbon and booze with a very nice warming effect.  Heavy vanilla and wonderful chocolate, toffee, oak, burnt raisins, dates, and a light touch of smoke.  Very heavy on the palate and offering a creamy mouthfeel.  This is just a wonderful beer!

Bottle at DLD shared by Chuck. Thanks! See, this is what I was expecting after all the old school hype surrounding BA Alesmith beers. Well integrated Barrel character in this one. Pours a chocolately brown with a tan creamy head. Nose is light vanilla and cocoa with a fullness to it. Not roast so much as really good chocolate. Clean. Bourbon is subdued overall. On taste, it seems to have lost a touch of the creaminess that has been replaced by an almost savory tobacco quality. Like oak spice and vanilla contribute as does more of the chocolate. This is a really delicious beer that I hope to try again someday for sure.

750 ml bottle shared by guyinchicago. Thanks, Chuck! Pours a deep brownish red hue, good haze, frothy tannish head dies to a small film. Aromas are rich and sweet, caramel and toffee mix into Bourbon, wet oak, touches of smoke, red fruit, and peat. Vanilla, doesnt get too sweet. Rich. Initial is sweet red fruit, toffee, big caramel. A strong ABV element comes into play with wet oak, big vanilla tannins. Hot and sweet, but dried out by the barrel a bit, hot and loaded with barrel tannins. Into the end, more red fruit, caramel, vanilla. Big wet oak and some hot spirit, some more cellar time could do it some good. But overall, a strong and assertive beer. Really glad to of tried it, its a huge step up from the base in intensity, sweet malts getting thinned a fair amount by the heat and big oaky presence.

Bottle of the 2005 from the OTM First Anniversary AleSmith tasting. The appearance is a deep amber brown with a micro head. A more still look. The aromas are great. The aromas are strong with a scotch aroma, very spirit forward with the oak poking through. More of an alcohol nose then a beer nose but really nice. The flavors are amazing. Great amounts of vanilla, chocolate truffles, oak, great maltiness.  Scotch flavors are subtle and are really rounded by the mellow vanilla and oak. Great great flavors. The mouth is full bodied with a thin feeling. Alcohol presence is pretty low with the age. Just outstanding brew.
Bottle. Pours dark red/brown with a small beige head. Aroma is booze, caramel, and mollasses. Flavor is caramel, nuts, mollasses, and vanilla. Medium mouthfeel with great heat.
aroma was very boozy with a hint of caramel chocolate and coffee. Appearance was dark brown with no head.  taste was sweet with raisins booze, vanilla, molasses. medium bodied with a creamy texture.

Pours a murky brown with non existent head. Aroma aroma is strong booze, and caramel. Raisins. Taste is caramel, vanilla, booze and malts. Palate is pretty good. Alcohol burn isnt as bad as youd think. This beers good. Im glad I tried

Huge thanks to Brad for sharing this bottle; Id been wanting to try this for quite some time. 2006 vintage. Bottle 246/254. Served in a snifter.

Pours a moderately-dark brown color with a single-finger tan head and a bit of light lacing and a thin collar. Nose brings quite a bit of caramel, barrel character, dark fruits, and some more bourbon. A bit of booze, though its quite welcome in the state its in.

Flavor is really quite exceptional with a really nice barrel character. Really smooth and mellow. Beautiful warmth in the finish coming from the alcohol. Slight sweetness comes alongside the dark fruit character. Medium body and quite complex. Good carbonation. Ive been waiting quite a long time to try this one, and it certainly was not a disappointment.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-19-2010

A: Not the prettiest looking beer.  A turbid brown/amber color with a small off-white head.

S: The wonders of barrel aging are immediately on display.  Rich bourbon, vanilla, and maple syrup with just a hint of the peat from the base Wee Heavy.  A little big of chocolate along with plenty of caramel.  Oh, a lot of bourbon, too.

T: Intense maple syrup flavor right away.  Very sweet with caramel, vanilla, and toffee being prominent contributors as well.  Although there is a lot of bourbon flavor, its not overly boozy.  Mild peat and smoke flavors, but theyre sort of overwhelmed.

M: Medium to full in body with a surprisingly ample amount of carbonation for a beer of this nature.

O: Just fantastic stuff.  Id be happy to drink this any day, though after having the previous release last year, Id say not the best candidate for aging.
750ml bottle.  Rating #288. Murky dark brown pour. Big dark fruit aroma, sweet, not a lot of bourbon that I could detect. Boozy, lots of bourbon and nice and sweet and delicious. (1563)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 2009 bottle... Pours a dark caramel brown, not much head though... The aroma is subtle but nice, caramel with dr. pepper, reminds me of a sweeter ba bw... The taste is touch weak and a light mouthfeel hurts the complexity factor. Really nice peat notes with sweet caramel, a little scotch finish.... Really good, just a touch muted to be outstanding.

Bottle shared by Brad at a recent tasting, 2006 vintge. About 250 of these were bottled, Im super honored to get a pour of this. Beer is dark brown and pretty hazy with a thin off white / tan head of small and medium bubbles. Agitation coaxes a decent head out of the beer but it does not have good staying power, minimal lacing.

Aroma is very bourbon filled. Its sweet and has some herbal spice to it but mostly liquor. Smells awesome honestly, exactly what I hoped it would smell like.

Beer is medium bodied and really creamy. There is minimal peat in the mid-palate and rounds out nicely to finish the beer. The lead off is a little sweet and very bourbon-y. It is not very hot, just a nice beer all around. The flavors walk that line between tasting like liquor and being liquor. I would have more of this if that were possible. As it is now Ill just have to lean on my memory.

Serving type: bottle

Courtesy of Daknole. #222/972 Bottle pours deep brown with no head.  Aroma shows notes of molasses, smoke, oak, brown sugar, bourbon, and roasted malt.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of caramel, fig, dates, and vanilla.  Overall body is full, viscous and finishes with a nice warming alc presence.

09 bottle.  Dark and hazy brown in the glass with a thin slick of foam.  Light ebb of carbonation on the edges of the glass.  Aroma is clean bourbon, vanilla, and oak and maybe some light toffee.  Taste is big and clean bourbon with light raisin and/or sweet malt in the middle with a smooth bourbon/alcohol presence through the finish that pleasantly lingers after each sip.  Tastes great with a velvet feel in the mouth.  In a blind tasting I would really have no idea that this is a scotch ale because the bourbon and oak completely dominates the flavor profile.  But it doesnt matter because the beer is so well done and ridiculously smooth.  I think I actually prefer this to the BA Old Numbskull because the base beer here provides a cleaner and more complimentary canvass for the bourbon/oak.  Absolute A+ sipping beer.

Bottle. Had this side by side with the regular version. This pours the same, brown with a light beige head. The aroma is bourbon, caramel, vanilla, and dark fruits. The flavor is a bit sweeter than the normal version. The bourbon flavor is pure finesse, not too much, not too little. A definite improvement on an already great beer.

Poured from a 750 and tasted side by side with the non-BA version.  Pour was a similar dark cola color but with no head to speak of.  Nose is malt, smoke and a lot of bourbon.  Taste has similarities to the original but it is much heavier on the mouth and the lack of carbonation only decreases the enjoyment for me.  Bottle lists ABV at 9.5% versus the 9.0% of the original which I find impossible to believe.   I am a little concerned that even after sitting in the bottle for 7 months before the release the carbonation has not come up.  I am hopeful that another year in the bottle for the rest in my cellar will it do it a lot of good.

Poured from 750 ML bottle from the 2010 release. Pours dark brown with almost no head at all.   Smell is vanilla, alcohol and bourbon.  This is pretty hot still...the alcohol dominates.  Taste is similar to the nose...vanilla, bourbon and burnt sugars.  It loses most of the original character of the Wee Heavy base beer, which remains one of my favorites.

bottle #60/972, courtesy of dasilky, thank you for this one! tried side by side with 2 bottles of fresh wee heavy. wow. i actually had never even tried the regular version, so this was a treat. great brew, tons of nice bourbon profile, nice body from the wee heavy. opened a bourbon drinkers eyes to ba beer with this one, excellent success! just terrific, slightly old ale feel. i think some of the intricate complexity of the original brew is list here, but i still love it of course. good stuff.

2010 released bottle.  Clear but deep dark mohagany.  Thin frothy head.  Bourbony vanilla nose...boozy though...malty flavors and bourbony vanilla.  Boozy though and failry low on carbonation..Im not as keen on this as I am on the original...I think theres more booze than there is bourbon flavor going on here...maybe its just drier than I would prefer, but Im not completely in love.

2009 bottle number 899 of 972. Thanks alex. nice aroma of carmel malt with some smokeyness. Not much head. Sweet smmoth flavor with a healrhy dose of boozw. Mellow finish.   Toffee and a bit nutty. Ive git more bottles at homeand well be interested to  see how it developed.

Thanks Joey for sharing this--2007 release. Dark brown-black with with a thin, fine dark tan head. Very full aroma of dark caramel, rich vanilla, and dried fruits with gorgeous oxidative characteristics. Tons of prune in the flavor with well-integrated Bourbon characteristics. This has aged extremely well, as Im sure the new 2011 release will as well.

New 2010 vintage bought yesterday at Alesmith. Dark brown cola pour with thin bubbly head that separated the in the glass. Tons of bourbon and dark fruits, brown sugar, vanilla in the aroma. Taste was surprisingly smooth compared to the aroma with tons of malts, oak, caramel and a touch of smokiness. Thin body but very pleasant to drink. Liked this way better than the regular version.

Bottle, thx for sharing tarheels. Pours dark brown with virtually no head (Probably because the bottle is 5+ years old). Aroma of bourbon, butterscotch, sweet malt, vanilla. Flavor is very bourbon heavy, maple syrup, vanilla. Lost a bit of body over the years but very drinkable and goes down easy with no booziness. I wouldnt say its necessarily better than regular Wee Heavy, just different, but in a good way. Great dessert beer.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2011 750mL gold foil bottle #213/222 2005 bottling released 2007 thanks to GCurlow. Pours a relatively still, clear, deep ruby brune. Really no head but some yellow bubbles escape. Swirling the glass, you get no glass staining like a sugar bomb but you are rewarded with some decent looking legs. Aroma is superlative bourbon pretty much: straight butterscotch, caramel, ultra rich toffee, vanilla, bourbon soaked cherries, black cherries, cocoa butter, Frangelico hazelnut liquor. I mean you could just smell this beer for a few hours. The taste is wickedly smooth with signs that it was once hot as a mofo seeing this is now almost six years old. Spicy and sweet dichotomy: tiramisu, chocolate ganache, vanilla ice cream, hazelnut gelato. A soft, warming sensation creeps upon you with subtle timidity. The only beer to compare this to is really CCB BA Big Sound. This is darker, softer, so much more vanilla and robustness. There is a spicy, sweet component, a slight maple syrup component and ever so light tartness. As it warms (Ive been savoring it for an hour) there is smooth caramel, cafe latte, rich and palatable coffee, mocha, astringent and dry coffee beans. But the palate isnt quite there. The body is a little thin being robbed of carbonation. The taste not as robust and rip your head off as the normal Wee Heavy. What is the best Scotch Ale in the world has been robbed of mouthfeel and bite but gained aroma and dessert, port like vinous character. It is a treat worth savoring but I cant say I like it better than its little brother. 1/10/2011 9/4/8/4/15=4.0750mL 2009 ed thanks to peteinSD. The pour is not looking so hot- really needs coaxing to generate a thin, tan head. Otherwise you are going to just get bubbles. Not really a problem for this barrel aged beer. Nose is rich buttery bourbon, coconut, cinnamon raisin cake, cinnamon schnapps. Not as wildly exquisite as the 2007 bottle. Tate is a little too much black cherry soda for me, very sweet and malty as expected with some saving grace in the form of velvety chocolate cake, cinnamon chocolate ganache. Mild spicy alcohol. Beautiful for what it is, a sweet coconut raisin dessert beer. Needs to be savored. 7/17/2011 8/3/8/5/16=4.0

Sepia body, thin white ring for a head. Tea leaves, maple syrup, earthy nose. Flavor has traditional lactose notes, more syrup, bubblegum, lightly sweet through finish. A bit off here and there, some off bitterness, light clash between malt dryness and sugars. Good Beer, but BA scotch is very similar to scotch. Really like the subtle Scotch ale notes with the additional sweetness and heat.

Big thanks to Kevin for sharing this one!

A-pours a dark brown color with red edges and a lighter tan head.

S-the nose brings some cooked greens, notes of bourbon, lots of malt body, very sugary with toffee and caramel. Light malt sweetness with notes of oxidation in the back.

T-lots more cooked green vegatables, very sugary, toffee and caramel, diry burnt brown sugar, creamy oak with notes of bourbon.  there is some more malt sweetness, hints of dried plums and slightly bitter.

M-full bodied and thick, very viscous but still smooth and creamy. lighter carabonation with an easy finish.

D-this is very sugary and rather thick and creamy.  hints of oxidation and nothing subtle to it.  seems to be to style but the flavors seem slightly jumbled together but not bad.

Bottle from a trade with cbkschubert. 2006 #78/222. Pours cloudy dark caramel color with tan head. Aromas of caramel, oak and vanilla. Sweet caramel and toffee flavors with some vanilla and oak. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Great brew. Thanks Craig.
Another bottle shared by Mr. Smith.  I typically am not a fan of scotch ales, but Alesmith hit one out of the park with this bad boy.  All kinds of sweet caramel and dark fruits flavors..

Bottle 32/222. Dark toffee colour. No head. Big alcohol and sweet dark malt. Alcohol first on the tongue and then great candy flavour. Makes me think I am drinking a Skor bar or a new Werthers candy. I would love to be able to buy Alesmith Wee Heavy candies by the case. I really like it but more as unique candy beer. I am tormented. Im not sure I like it so much as beer as I love it as a candy flavoured treat.

Plenty of oak, bourbon, raisins, toffee, chocolate and sweet dark fruits in the nose.  Alcohol is apparent.  Opaque brown body is topped by a low white head fully diminishing head.  Flavour offers bourbon, scotch, rum, chocolate, toffee, mint, vanilla, nuts and oak.  Alcohol is notable in the aftertaste especially.  Medium full body with somewhat low carbonation and strong alcohol warming.  Chalice.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (2005 vintage #32/222).  Sampled at presarios Als vs Stamps tasting.

Alesmith Wee Heavy Barrel Aged #127, HUGE thanks to WeeHeavySD for the trade and KimJohansen for bringing this home. Pours dark brown with a small white head. Aroma is dark malty and fruity. Dark malty base flavour yet on the sweet side. Persisting caramelish. Slight more dry malty into the finish. Dark caramelish lasting impression. Subdued bitter and dark malty finish.

2006 bottle at the Tally tasting, I think I got this from Kyle, so thank you, this stuff was near perfect.  Pours dark brown with a tall dark tan head.  Aroma is strong bourbon and vanilla with some nuts and doughy malt notes.  Flavor is so freaking mellow, slightly sweet and sour biscuit malts, very doughy with some yeast character and a strong malty, alcoholic, barrel finish.  This stuff is insane.

Courtesy of Hopscotch. Clear dark orange color, film for head. Aroma and flavor dominated by bourbon. Only hints of any malt left from the original beer. Through the finish the bourbon/vanilla character becomes very cloying. not my thing.
6/26/10.  Sampled at the Tally Tasting 2010 with HUGE thanks to fata2683.  Awesomely sweet and a dash of smokiness.  Subdued, subtle, and complex.  Mmmm.

Appearance: 2006 vintage, bottle 63 of 254, drank side by side with the 06 barrel-aged Old Numbskull. Dark ruddy brown in color, opaque except for some slight transparency around the edges. A thin tan head forms from a vigorous pour, settling quickly to a ring. This is slightly more carbonated than the barrel-aged Old Numbskull, but its by no means bubbly.

Smell: Rich and malty with a big oak barrel presence. Nutty, toasty, semi-sweet. Hints of vanilla and figs. This has a cleaner aroma than the barrel-aged Old Numbskull.

Taste & mouthfeel: Chewy toasted malt, tobacco and earth, chocolate and vanilla, huge oak flavor but not overtly bourbony. Malty, but drier than I was expecting. This is a mellow beer to begin with, but barrel aging has smoothed it out even more. No heat whatsoever despite the high ABV, and the low carbonation makes for a silky mouthfeel. Excellent stuff, not quite as outstanding as BA Speedway, but clearly better than BA Old Numbskull.
chocolate, alcohol, raisin, vanilla, woody, brown, cloudy, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, full body, thick feel, flat, long finish, nr.15

Bottle 190 of 222 from 2005.  Closed out a great weekend of beer ratings with this gem - thanks to my cousin!  Nice dark green bottle.  Dark brown pour, auburn hilites, and no foam.  Strong fruity, smoky, bourbon aroma.  A rich, fine brew with lots of bourbon sweetness.  Smooth on the palate with a nice hoppy prickle.  As good a bourbon barrel aged scotch ale as I can think of.

2006 750ml bottle...thanks to S.FL guys for sharing this gem with me. Pours murky brown with a tan head. Nose is full of cherry, raisin, dark fruit and sweet malts. Flavor is similar to nose with oak coming out as well, lots of sour cherry which extends into the finish. Great beer.

#1600 !!  2005 version bottle # 190/222.  Pours a dark maple brown with no head.  Huge bourbon aroma with notes of dates, raisins, vanilla, figs and dark sugar.  Taste of bourbon, dates, raisins, prunes, vanilla, oak, figs and dark sugar.  Superb.

2006 vintage graciosly shared by guyinchicago. Thanks Chuck. My 700th rating. Murky brown pour with a light tan head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, bourbon, dark fruit, roasted malt. Taste is lightly carbonated with notes of bourbon, dark fruit, caramel, toffee, roated malt, some oak. Nicely balaced. Even the aroma had a great balance to it. This brew tasted great-so flavorful you almost didnt want to swallow.

2006 Bottle #16  thanks to giascar and a trade after 2009 DLD, brought this one to DLD2010 to share with many poured light brown thin tan head aromas of caranel,vanilla,bourbon and oak the flavor and feel was soft and smooth very mellow with all the above mentioned in taste,this one aged very gracefully

750ml Bottle. 2006 vintage. Big thanks to Zathrus13. Big want for me, and a birthday gift to a friend which he of course was more than happy to share. Nose is huge notes of wood, bourbon, brown sugar and sherry. Nose suggests light oxidiation, but nothing off putting. Flavor is full and rich with a huge mouthfeel. Up front tons of brown sugar war with big notes of fig and cherry. Finishes with a slight bourbon note of wood and vanilla and a long lingering brandied cherry flavor. Definitely some light oxidation. Even so a truly marvelous beer. I could drink this stuff all day, no alcohol burn at all and just so damn tasty. Id love to try a younger vintage which I suspect may have a little more bourbon and less fruity notes. Once again big thanks to Jeff for this one.

Bottle 750ml.Bottle #15/222. Clear medium to dark brown color with virtually none head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, coconut, bourbon - port, wood, vanilla. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate. Body is medium to full, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is flat to soft, finish feel is light to moderate alcoholic. [20100416]

I saw GuyInChicago grasping a bottle of this at DLD2010 and almost passed out with excitement (at least I think it was excitement.  Im sticking with excitement).  Dark reddish brown with tan head.  Aroma of oak, wood, tanins, some mild sweetness with a bit of earth and bourbon.  Flavor is ridiculously smooth, toffee and caramel nestled with smooth oak and bourbon.  Medium bodied, goes down really smoothly.  Finishes peaty with dark fruit sweetness.  One of the highlights of DLD2010.

750ml bottle via trade, huge thanks to kramer, who is extremely generous.  2006 vintage.  At the time of writing, this is the 83rd Top 100 beer on RB Ive tried.  Yes, Im a ridiculous ticker.

Pours dark brown, fairly clear, with a small tan head and good lacing.

Great aroma.  You can tell this one has some age.  Sweet caramel malt and sherry, light peaty smokiness, wood, and old leather.  Smells pretty awesome, even if those flavors might sound unappetizing to some.

Flavor is lots of caramel malt along with some toffee notes.  Sweet nuttiness, peat, wood, vanilla, and sherry oxidation flavors make this a really interesting and complex beer.

Medium-full bodied and very smooth.  Low carbonation, and a little alcohol warming.  Long finish.

What an awesome beer.  If this wasnt so rare, Id definitely seek it out again.  Easy to drink for what it is.

2005 Bottle Nr. 15/220. @ Brugmansia/Fonefan US Tasting, April 2010. Pours dark unclear brown with a small bubbly head on top. Nose is very vinous. Port, oak, toffee, vanilla and dark fruit. Medium and smooth palate. Low carbonation. Havy and complex with vague alcohol in the background. Reminds me a bit of Bourbon county stout. Pleasant warmth. Very tasty!

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2012 Late entry from Noogfest High Five.  2004, not sure what bottle number.   Sweet malty alcohol.  Peaty, caramel, scottish.  Yummy, Yummy.  Again at  the Irish Hanukkah Tasting for Drakes 5k.  Better second time around. 2009 bottle.  Big caramelized molasses and boozy bourbon.

This review is for the 2006 vintage, bottle 150/254.

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color thats completely opaque with dark ruby/mahogany edges when held to a light source and a thin half finger light beige head that quickly fades into a thin lasting ring.

Amazing complex aroma with lots of smokey roasted chocolate malt, caramel, toffee, roasted coffee bean, licorice, earthy oak, vanilla and a very prominent bourbon presence.

Slightly hot medium body with a nice, silky viscous malt presence with lots of chocolate, roasted coffee bean, burnt toast, caramel and licorice. Very roasty with subtle hops and a huge bourbon presence that is slightly hot and somewhat dominates the flavor. It isnt too overpowering however, allowing the other notes to shine. Slight tannis and a heavy oak and vanilla presence. Absolutely delicious! Highly recommended.

Bottle shared at puzzls New Years Eve 2009: (Thanks Max!) 2006 version- bottle 114/254. Murky muddy brown pour with a tan ring of head. Huge raisiny toffeeish, rummy, some bourbon and toasted oak and toasted coconut qualities in the aroma. Quite complex. The palate os soft and silky. The flavor has a tartish dark fruit note- a raisiny richness with toasted coconut, underlying tobacco, smooth vanilla/rummy notes, toasted oak and smooth toffee. A gentle giant filled with nuance and quite balanced. I think another year it would be at its peak. Nice.

From the Christmas tasting. The bottle was from 2006 at nr. 4/254. The pour is dark moshy brown with allmost no head. The aroma is classic bourbon aged. The trademarks with vanilla and sweet coconut dominates with a twist of salmiak - allmost like a pina colada gone rocknroll. The taste has also the bourbon barrels up front and specially the finish is packed with coconut. The main taste impression is sweet and sour - wome vinegar, vanilla and alcohol. Again I must admit the bourbons are not among my favourits.

In short: A fruity whisky with some port wine.  Very good but totally different (and inferior) to the regular version.
How: Bottle 750ml.  2005 release, bottle 210/222.  Consumed when about 3 year of age.  Sent to me by WeeHeavySD, thanks a lot Jon.
The look: Dark purple body (weird color) with almost no head
In long: Pleasant nose blending dark fruits with lots of bourbon.  Really smells like a fruity whisky.  Taste is single malt whisky, dark fruits juice, port wine and a lot of sweetness.   Body is syrupy and rather lifeless.  Just for fun (and because I like to do that type of things) I had a full bottle of the regular Wee Heavy and a bottle of this Barrel Aged version side-by-side.  This is actually a pretty damn good sweet sipper but it just doesnt compare to the regular AleSmith Wee Heavy which is one of my favourite Scotch Ale.  This is an original sipper, something I would gladly drink on occasion if I could by it at a normal price at a store.  Unfortunately in my neck of woods the bottles of this beer come as often as your grandfather without blue pills, and twice as expensive as the said blue pills.

Aroma: Dried dark fruit, tobacco, vanilla, anise, peat, cinnamon raisin bread.

Appearance: Pours a rootbeer brown with a 1/8 inch frothy tan head.

Aroma: Smokey malt, wood, vanilla bourbon notes and port wine.

Taste: Sweet bourbon notes, peaty malt, vanilla, dark fruit, spicy hops and wood.

Pours ruby brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma is sweet berry and honey with roast malt and vanilla. Taste is rich sweetness of dark fruit and caramel.

750 ml bottle shared with Crosling and Rye726 poured a cloudy dark brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of carmel, oak, molases, light bourbon and light dark fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, molasses, dark fruit, oak and light bourbon with a smooth lingering carmely finish. A bit of a disappointment this one.

750ml bottle. 2006 # 182/254. Man... when I opened this one up, the aroma was all solvent, chemical and harsh alcohol. Brutal. Let it sit for about an hour and things have toned down... a bit. Lots of bourbon, vanilla extract, charred caramel. Plenty of wet wood. But still, there is a harsh chemical aspect to the aroma. Especially isovaleric acid upon warming. Stinky sock crossed with wood tannin. Bizarre and slightly off-putting. The cap popped off without a hiss at all. A vigorous pour yields a nearly still beer. Dark, dark cola brown with a thin ring of khaki around the edge of the glass. Thankfully, the beer doesnt taste as bad as it smells, though it lacks in complexity. The flavor is really dominated by the barrel aging. And not necessarily bourbon, per se, just lots and lots of wood presence. Dry oak, vanilla and coconut extract. Dry toffee, bitter bakers chocolate.  Really lacks the chewy, malty, smoky complexity of the regular, non BA offering. Not a whole lot to say. It doesnt taste bad at all, just lacks something. Medium bodied on the tongue. Firm texture. Fairly lively carbonation despite the near lifeless pour. Dry throughout the palate especially on the finish. 
Honestly, a big disappointment. I love the regular AS WH, and I was convinced that this one would rise to the top of my BA AS ratings, but the absolute chemical aspect of the nose and the lack of complexity on the palate really let me down. Its not a bad beer by any stretch... Maybe just not suited for aging. Perhaps the fresher BA bottles are the ones to drink. Oh well... Thanks Marc!

4th September 2008. The saltiness of the non barrel version is now emphasised. Vanilla dominates and woody tones come to the fore surpressing the chocolate of the non barrelled version. Spirity warmth in the finish. Nice beer but the barreling detracts from the base beer in this case.

2006 bottle drank in 9/09

Nose has lots of run-raisin, bourbon, smoke, and brown sugar. 
Taste is apple, bourbon, liquid smoke, molasses, beautiful balance of sweet with astringent.

750ml bottle # 98 / 254....2006.  Pours a deep cola brown with a frothy sea foam like beige head.  Nose hold a good amount of bourbon, vanilla and light oxidation.  I pick up aromas of black cherry and caramel as well.  Some flavors of tobacco, brown sugar, bourbon, vanilla and roasted malts.  A great brew, might have been even better about 6 months ago.....

2005 Bottle  Shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad!  Rating #1900  Dark brown, off white creamy head.  Bold sweet bourbon and burnt caramelized toffee chip aromas warm to swirls of dark fruits and vanilla oak.  Toasty brown sugar and boozy coconut flavors are well textured over soft layers of old vanilla wood and fruity smoke from beginning to end. Full bodied and smooth, pillow soft carbonation, soft bourbon oak finish.  One word.spectacular

Thanks to Sam for this one.  06 bottle.  Dark brown body.  Aroma has lots of bourbon, vanilla, light tobacco, sweet brown sugar.  Flavor is heavy with bourbon, has some brown sugar, and a lactic touch.  Light peat and tobacco round it out.  Body is thick and syrupy.

Bottle,this was a good scotch  ale before added to bourbon barrel,the bourbon is way to overpowering and makes this  a okay beer with hints of chocolate and vanilla,very sweet and almost no head.CHEERS!!

Thanks a ton mike.  this beer is fucking awesome. 2006 release.  # 130/254.   blown away.  nice smooth peat, bourbon, vanilla.  at a loss for words.  one of the best beers ive ever had.  smooth, complex, beyond tasty. 2006 bottle 170 something (it rubbed off so I cant see the last number).  Pours dark brown nearing black with very small tan head.  Smells strongly of oak/whiskey.
